PAPERLESS ORDER. THIS MATTER is before the Court sua sponte. On April 2, 2025, Plaintiffs filed an Expedited Motion for a Temporary Restraining Order and Preliminary Injunction (DE 4) ("Motion"). In the Motion, Plaintiffs request the Court grant a temporary restraining order preventing enforcement of Florida law S.B. 4-C pending consideration of Plaintiffs' request for a preliminary injunction. (DE 4 at 1, 20.) A court may not grant a temporary restraining order without notice to the adverse party unless "the movant's attorney certifies in writing any efforts made to give notice and the reasons why it should not be required." Fed. R. Civ. P. 65(b)(1)(B). Further, Southern District of Florida Local Rule 7.1(d)(2) requires that an expedited motion "set forth in detail the date by which an expedited ruling is needed and the reason the ruling is needed by the stated date." Plaintiffs have not filed proof of service of any Defendants, and the Motion does not describe any other efforts made to give notice to Defendants or any reason why notice should not be required. The Motion also fails to set forth a date by which an expedited ruling is needed with accompanying reasoning. Accordingly, it is ORDERED AND ADJUDGED that Plaintiffs shall comply with Rule 65(b)(1)(B) and Local Rule 7.1(d)(2) on or before April 4, 2025. Signed by Judge Kathleen M. Williams on 4/3/2025. (cgd) (Entered: 04/03/2025)

PAPERLESS ORDER. THIS MATTER is before the Court on Plaintiffs and Defendants Attorney General James Uthmeier and Statewide Prosecutor Nicholas B. Cox's Joint Motion to stay Defendants' deadline to respond to the Complaint and all discovery deadlines (DE 34 ) and Plaintiffs and the State Attorney Defendants' Joint Motion for a Stay of Deadlines to Respond to Complaint and Discovery Deadlines (DE 39 ) (together "Motions to Stay"). In the Motions to Stay, all Parties request a stay of Defendants' joint response deadline and the Parties' discovery deadlines in light of the impact that Plaintiffs' pending Motion for Preliminary Injunction (DE 4 ) ("Motion for PI") will have on the case and the likelihood any order on the Motion for PI will be appealed. See Pinares v. United Techs. Corp., No. 10-80883-CIV, 2019 WL 8129287, at *1 (S.D. Fla. Feb. 12, 2019) (using the "district court['s] broad discretion to stay its own proceedings" pending appeal because the appellate ruling would likely simplify the issues and no party would be unduly prejudiced by the stay). Upon review of the Motions and the record, it is ORDERED AND ADJUDGED that the Motions to Stay (DE 34 ; DE 39 ) are GRANTED. Defendants' deadline to respond to the Complaint (DE 1 ) and the Parties' discovery deadlines are STAYED until further order of the Court. All other deadlines remain in place. Signed by Judge Kathleen M. Williams on 4/21/2025. (cgd) (Entered: 04/21/2025)

PAPERLESS ORDER. THIS MATTER is before the Court on Defendants' Motion for a Stay Pending Appeal of Preliminary Injunction (DE 69 ) ("Motion"). In the Motion, Defendants request a stay of the Preliminary Injunction (DE 67 ) pending appeal, or alternatively, a stay pending appeal of the Preliminary Injunction to the extend it binds law enforcement officers in Florida. (DE 69 at 2.) Defendants later moved for the same relief on the same grounds before the Eleventh Circuit. Appellants' Motion to Stay Injunction Pending Appeal, Fla. Immigrant Coal. v. Att'y Gen., Fla., 25-11469 (11th Cir. May 7, 2025), ECF 6. The Eleventh Circuit denied Defendants' motion. Fla. Immigrant Coal., 25-11469 (11th Cir. June 6, 2025), ECF 24. District courts "are generally bound by findings of fact and conclusions of law made by the court of appeals in a prior appeal of the same case." Wheeler v. City of Pleasant Grove, 746 F.2d 1437, 1440 (11th Cir. 1984); see also Schiavo ex rel. Schindler v. Schiavo, 403 F.3d 1289, 1291 (11th Cir. 2005) ("Under the law-of-the-case doctrine, the resolution of an issue decided at one stage of case is binding at later stages of the same case.... The doctrine operates to preclude courts from revisiting issues that were decided... in a prior appeal.") (cleaned up). Accordingly, upon review of the record, the Motion, and the applicable law, it is ORDERED AND ADJUDGED that the Motion (DE 69 ) is DENIED. Signed by Judge Kathleen M. Williams on 6/16/2025. (cgd) (Entered: 06/16/2025)

PAPERLESS ORDER. THIS MATTER is before the Court sua sponte. On April 29, 2025, the Court granted Plaintiffs' Motion for Preliminary Injunction. (DE 67 .) The same night, Defendants filed a Notice of Interlocutory Appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit ("Eleventh Circuit"). (DE 68 .) On April 30, 2025, Defendants filed a Motion for Stay Pending Appeal of Preliminary Injunction (DE 69 ) ("Motion for Stay"). Defendants did not request an expedited ruling or briefing schedule for the Motion to Stay, so the Court maintained the usual briefing schedule specified in Local Rule 7.1(c)(1). S.D. Fla. L.R. 7(c)(1) (generally requiring a response within fourteen days of a motion's filing and any reply within seven days of the response). Pursuant to that schedule, any reply by Defendants is due by May 21, 2025. On May 7, 2025, despite the requirement that a "party must ordinarily move first in the district court for... a stay of the judgment or order of a district court pending appeal[,]" including "an order suspending, modifying, restoring, or granting an injunction," Defendants moved in the Eleventh Circuit for a stay of the injunction pending appeal. Fed. R. App. P. 8(a)(1); see Appellants' Motion to Stay Injunction Pending Appeal, Fla. Immigrant Coal. v. Att'y Gen., Fla., 25-11469 (11th Cir. May 7, 2025), ECF 6. The motion filed before the Eleventh Circuit did not include a "show[ing] that moving first in the district court would be impracticable[.]" Fed. R. App. P. 8(a)(2)(A)(i). Five days later, Defendants requested the Eleventh Circuit to expedite briefing and ruling on their request. See Appellants' Time-Sensitive Motion to Expedite Consideration of Stay Pending Appeal and to Expedite Appeal, Fla. Immigrant Coal., 25-11469 (11th Cir. May 12, 2025), ECF 12. A Court "retain[s] jurisdiction to grant [a] request for a stay despite the fact that a notice of appeal... was filed prior to the request for a stay." Matter of Miranne, 852 F.2d 805, 806 (5th Cir. 1988) (citing Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 62); see also Doe v. Trump, 284 F. Supp. 3d 1172, 1176 (W.D. Wash. 2018) (concluding the court had "jurisdiction to consider [d]efendants' emergency motion to stay the preliminary injunction despite the pending appeal[,]" as part of "preserv[ing] the status quo or ensur[ing] compliance with its earlier orders") (citations omitted). Nonetheless, in order to avoid the usual problems that counsel against district and circuit courts exercising "dual jurisdiction[,]" now that Defendants have filed a duplicate motion to stay in the Eleventh Circuit, the Court will wait to consider Defendants' Motion to Stay (DE 69 ) until the Eleventh Circuit indicates its position on this matter. United States v. Roemmele, 506 F. App'x 891, 892 (11th Cir. 2013) (describing the general rule, based on interests of judicial economy and fairness to parties, that when an appeal is filed, "the district court is divested of jurisdiction to take any action with regard to the matter except in aid of the appeal") (emphasis in the original) (quotations omitted). Signed by Judge Kathleen M. Williams on 5/19/2025. (cgd) (Entered: 05/19/2025)

PAPERLESS ORDER. THIS MATTER is before the Court on Defendants' Motion for Clarification (DE 32 ) ("Motion"). In the Motion, Defendants request clarification regarding "whether the hearing will involve only issues on the motion for preliminary injunction, or whether the Court also desires to hear from the parties about the motion for class certification." The Court notes that a briefing schedule has been entered on Plaintiffs' Motion for Class Certification. (DE 5 .) Upon review of the record and the Motion, it is ORDERED AND ADJUDGED that the Motion (DE 32 ) is GRANTED. During the Preliminary Injunction Hearing, the Court will hear arguments on the Motion for Preliminary Injunction (DE 4 ). However, to the extent the Parties believe a determination on the class certification issue is relevant to and would impact the viability of injunctive relief, the Parties may address this issue in their submissions on Plaintiffs' Motion for Preliminary Injunction and at the Hearing. Defendants' April 16, 2025 deadline to respond to Plaintiffs' Motion for Class Certification (DE 5 ) remains unchanged. Signed by Judge Kathleen M. Williams on 4/12/2025. (cgd) (Entered: 04/12/2025)

case_data.name: Florida Immigrant Coalition v. Uthmeier
case_data.plaintiff_description: The Farmworker Association of Florida (FWAF), the Florida Immigrant Coalition (FLIC), and an individual plaintiff and member of the FLIC.
case_data.summary:
This case challenged a Florida law that criminalizes undocumented immigrants’ presence in the state. On April 2, 2025, the Florida Immigrant Coalition (FLIC) and the Farmworker Association of Florida (FWAF), along with two anonymous individual plaintiffs, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida. The plaintiffs, represented by the ACLU Immigrants’ Rights Project, Americans for Immigrant Justice, and the Community Justice Project, sued the Florida Attorney General, the Statewide Prosecutor, and all twenty elected State Attorneys in their official capacities. The plaintiffs alleged that Senate Bill 4-C (“SB 4-C”)—which created new state crimes for “unauthorized” immigrants entering or remaining in Florida—was unconstitutional. They claimed that the law was preempted by federal immigration law in violation of the Supremacy Clause and violated the Dormant Commerce Clause. Plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, class certification. 

The case was assigned to Judge Kathleen M. Williams. 

SB 4-C, enacted in 2024 and codified at Florida Statutes §§ 811.102 and 811.103, created two felony offenses: the first criminalized knowingly entering Florida after entering the United States unlawfully; the second criminalized reentering or remaining in Florida after being deported or removed from the country. The law incorporated federal immigration law terms and carved out exceptions where the federal government had granted lawful presence. The plaintiffs argued that despite these references, the law intruded into an area exclusively governed by federal authority. 

Alongside their complaint, plaintiffs filed an emergency motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO), a motion for a preliminary injunction (PI), and a motion for class certification. On April 3, the district court initially denied the TRO for failure to comply with local rules, but granted the TRO the next day after supplemental briefing. 778 F.Supp.3d 1315. The court enjoined enforcement of SB 4-C statewide for fourteen days, finding plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their preemption and Commerce Clause claims and faced irreparable harm.

After the TRO went into effect, plaintiffs reported that local law enforcement officers continued to make arrests under SB 4-C. In response, the court clarified that its injunction extended to any Florida law enforcement officer with authority to enforce the statute. The defendants objected that this improperly bound non-parties and violated Federal Rule Civ. Pro. 65 (i.e. violated the injunction). The court rejected those arguments and, on April 29, 2025, granted a PI, again enjoining all enforcement of SB 4-C by any state or local officer. 780 F.Supp.3d 1235. It also provisionally certified two Rule 23(b)(2) classes representing all individuals reasonably at risk of prosecution under either section of the law. The court ordered the Attorney General to show cause why his public statements questioning the order’s scope did not violate the injunction. 

On April 30, the defendants filed a notice of appeal to the Eleventh Circuit and moved to stay the injunction pending appeal. The district court declined to rule on the stay request, deferring to the appellate court. On June 6, a motions panel of the Eleventh Circuit denied the stay. The panel concluded that the state had not shown a strong likelihood of success on the merits, finding that SB 4-C was likely subject to "field preemption" by the federal Immigration and Nationality Act. The court declined to stay the injunction even in part, leaving intact the provision binding non-party law enforcement officers. 

On June 17, the Florida Attorney General filed an emergency application with Justice Clarence Thomas, seeking a stay of the injunction from the U.S. Supreme Court pending appeal and, if necessary, future proceedings in that Court. 787 F.Supp.3d 1323. The application argued that SB 4-C merely tracked federal law and that the district court exceeded its authority by binding non-parties. It also claimed the injunction imposed irreparable harm on the state’s sovereign interests and exposed officials to contempt for conduct they could not control. On July 9, the Supreme Court justices without comment denied a request to allow the state to enforce SB 4-C. 

The case remains ongoing.
case_data.summary_short: This case challenged Florida Senate Bill 4-C, a 2024 state law that created two new immigration-related felonies. On April 2, 2025, two nonprofit organizations and two individual plaintiffs filed a class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida. They sued the Florida Attorney General, Statewide Prosecutor, and all 20 elected State Attorneys. Represented by the ACLU Immigrantsโ Rights Project, Americans for Immigrant Justice, and the Community Justice Project, the plaintiffs alleged that SB 4-C was preempted by federal immigration law and violated the Dormant Commerce Clause. The court issued a temporary restraining order on April 4 and granted a preliminary injunction on April 29, barring enforcement of the law by any state or local official. The court also provisionally certified two plaintiff classes. Defendants sought a stay from the Eleventh Circuit and then the U.S. Supreme Court. On July 9, the Supreme Court justices without comment denied a request to allow the state to enforce SB 4-C. As of July 10, the preliminary injunction remains in effect. The case is ongoing.

documents.title: Order
documents.text:
Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 96   Entered on FLSD Docket 06/17/2025   Page 1 of 27
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA 
CASE NO. 25-21524-CV-WILLIAMS 
 
FLORIDA IMMIGRANT COALITION, et al., 
 
Plaintiffs, 
 
v. 
 
JAMES UTHMEIER, et al., 
 
  Defendants. 
                 / 
 
ORDER 
THIS MATTER is before the Court following the April 29, 2025 Order requiring 
Florida Attorney General James Uthmeier (โUthmeierโ or โAG Uthmeierโ) to show cause 
โwhy he should not be held in contempt or sanctioned for violating this Courtโs [Temporary 
Restraining Order (โTROโ)] (DE 28; DE 49)[.]โ (DE 67 at 48โ49 (โShow Cause Orderโ).) 
Uthmeier filed a Response to Order to Show Cause (DE 81) (โShow Cause Responseโ), 
and Plaintiffs filed their own response brief (DE 87). The Court heard further arguments 
from the Parties at a May 29, 2025 Show Cause Hearing. (DE 89.) For the reasons set 
forth below, the Court finds that Uthmeier is in civil contempt of the Courtโs April 18, 2025 
Order that Defendants shall โprovide actual notice of the TROโ to all โlaw enforcement 
officer[s] with power to enforce [S.B.] 4-C.โ (DE 49.) 
I.  INTRODUCTION 
On April 18, 2025, the Court clarified that law enforcement officers within Florida 
were bound by a TRO enjoining enforcement of the newly enacted criminal immigration 
Page 1 of 27 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 96   Entered on FLSD Docket 06/17/2025   Page 2 of 27
law,  Florida  Senate  Bill  4-C  (โS.B.  4-Cโ  or  the  โStatuteโ),1  and  the  Court  ordered 
Defendants to โprovide actual notice of the TROโ to all โlaw enforcement officer[s] with 
power to enforce S.B. 4-C.โ (DE 49.) Uthmeier initially complied, sending a letter to law 
enforcement agency heads. (DE 57-2) (โApril 18th Letterโ) (โthe [C]ourt directed my office 
to notify your agencies of its clarification that law enforcement officers should take no 
steps to enforce [S.B. 4-C], including through arrests or detentions . . . . โPlease instruct 
your officers and agents to comply with Judge Williamsโ directives.โ). But on April 23, 
2025, Uthmeier sent a follow-up letter to the law enforcement community (โApril 23rd 
Letterโ), telling them, โno judicial order . . . properly restrains you fromโ enforcing S.B. 4-
C and that โno lawful, legitimate order currently impedes your agencies from continuing 
to enforceโ the enjoined statute. (DE 57-1 at 2.)  
In  his  Show  Cause  Response,  Uthmeier  posits  a  series  of  implausible 
interpretations of the language he used to argue that his April 23rd Letter does not conflict 
with or undermine the notice he gave in his April 18th Letter. And while insisting that the 
meaning the Court should attach to his statements in the April 23rd Letter is that he is fully 
 
1  Broadly,  S.B.  4-C  creates  two  new  state  law  offenses:  โIllegal  entry  by  adult 
unauthorized alien into this stateโ and โIllegal reentry of an adult unauthorized alien.โ Fla. 
Stat. ยงยง 811.102โ103. Section 811.102(1) prohibits any โunauthorized alien who is 18 
years of age or olderโ from โknowingly enter[ing] or attempt[ing] to enterโ Florida โafter 
entering  the  United  States  by  eluding  or  avoiding  examination  or  inspection  by 
immigration  officersโ  (โillegal  entryโ).  Under  subsection  811.103(1),  an  adult 
โunauthorized alienโ commits a third-degree felony, if they โenter[], attempt[] to enter, or  
[are]  at  any  time  found  inโ  Florida  after  โhaving  been  denied  admission,  excluded, 
deported, or removed or having departed the United States during the time an order of 
exclusion,  deportation,  or  removal  is  outstandingโ  (โillegal  reentryโ).  Fla.  Stat.  ยง 
811.103(1).  The  Statute  has  several  other  provisions  governing  pre-trial  detention, 
sentencing, affirmative defenses, and required cooperation between the arresting agency 
and  other  state  and  local  law  enforcement  agencies.  Fla.  Stat.  ยงยง  811.102(2)โ(7), 
811.103(2)โ(6). 
Page 2 of 27 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 96   Entered on FLSD Docket 06/17/2025   Page 3 of 27
compliant with the Courtโs order, Uthmeier publicly disavowed his compliance on multiple 
occasionsโstating he would not โbow downโ to the Court, among other comments. 
Before analyzing Uthmeierโs arguments, the Court will recount a more fulsome factual 
and procedural history of this case. 
II.  BACKGROUND 
A. Procedural history leading up to show cause proceedings 
On April 2, 2024, Plaintiffs2 filed a Class Action Complaint (DE 1), seeking (1) a 
declaration  that  S.B.  4-C  violates  the  United  States  Constitutionโs  Supremacy  and 
Commerce Clauses, and (2) injunctive relief barring enforcement of S.B. 4-C by state and 
local officials. (DE 1 ยถยถ 2, 5, 40.) The suit names all state prosecutorial authoritiesโAG 
Uthmeier, Statewide Prosecutor Nicholas B. Cox, and the State Attorneys for the twenty 
Florida judicial circuitsโas Defendants. (Id. ยถยถ 30โ32.) That same day, Plaintiffs filed an 
Expedited Motion for Temporary Restraining Order and Preliminary Injunction (DE 4).3 
On April 4, 2025, the Court entered a TRO โprohibiting Defendants and their officers, 
agents, employees, attorneys, and any person[s] who are in active concert or participation 
with them from enforcingโ S.B. 4-C for fourteen days. (DE 28 at 14.)  
Then, on April 18, 2025, the Court held a hearing to determine whether to convert 
the TRO into a preliminary injunction. (DE 48.) At the hearing, Plaintiffs informed the Court 
that law enforcement had made at least thirteen arrests pursuant to S.B. 4-C since the 
 
2 Plaintiffs include individuals V.V. and Y.M., who allege they are at risk of arrest and 
prosecution  under  the  Statute,  and  two  grassroots  membership  organizations, 
Farmworker Association of Florida, Inc. and Florida Immigrant Coalition, which support 
members who are similarly at risk. (DE 1 ยถยถ 8, 11โ24, 26โ28.) 
3 Plaintiffs also filed a Motion for Class Certification (DE 5). The Court granted provisional 
class certification on April 29, 2025. (DE 67 at 47.) 
Page 3 of 27 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 96   Entered on FLSD Docket 06/17/2025   Page 4 of 27
entry of the TRO. (DE 50 at 12.) Defendants argued that law enforcement agencies, who 
were not named parties, were not covered under the TRO, and could lawfully continue 
making arrests pursuant to a law for which no prosecution could follow. (Id. at 12โ15.) To 
clarify that the TRO foreclosed Defendantsโ position and to ensure the TRO provided 
Plaintiffs true relief, the Court entered the following Order (DE 49) (โApril 18th Orderโ) 
extending the timeline of the TRO and clarifying its scope: 
1.  The Temporary Restraining Order (โTROโ) (DE 28) is EXTENDED and shall 
remain in effect through April 29, 2025 at 5:00 p.m. or until further order of 
the Court. The TRO shall be interpreted to include among those โwho are 
in active concert or participation withโ Defendants or their officers, agents, 
employees, or attorneys, and thus prohibited from enforcing SB 4-C, the 
following: any officer or other personnel within any municipal or county 
police  department  within  Florida,  the  Florida  Department  of  Law 
Enforcement, or the Florida Highway Patrol, and any other law enforcement 
officer with power to enforce [S.B.] 4-C. (DE 28 at 14); see also Fed. R. Civ. 
P.  65(d)(2)(C)  (including  โother  persons  who  are  in  active  concert  or 
participation  withโ  the  parties  or  the partiesโ  officers,  agents,  servants, 
employees, and attorneys among those bound by any TRO). The TRO shall 
also be interpreted to prohibit any person covered by the TRO from filing or 
maintaining any charge pursuant to Florida Statutes section 811.102 or 
811.103. 
 
2.  Defendants shall IMMEDIATELY provide actual notice of the TRO to all 
named Defendants and their officers, agents, employees, attorneys, and 
any person who is in active concert or participation with them and who has 
not already received actual notice [(โactual notice requirementโ or โactual 
notice mandateโ)]. 
 
(DE 49 (emphasis omitted).) The April 18th Order also set a briefing schedule and Status 
Conference for April 29, 2025 to resolve the Partiesโ disagreement over the proper scope 
of injunctive relief. (Id. at 2.)  Immediately following the April 18th Order, Uthmeier sent his 
April 18th Letter to the law enforcement community, which complied with the actual notice 
mandate. In his correspondenceโdisseminated by email and posted on social mediaโ
Uthmeier laid out his disagreement with the Courtโs legal conclusions, and informed the 
Page 4 of 27 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 96   Entered on FLSD Docket 06/17/2025   Page 5 of 27
recipients of his intent to appeal the scope of the injunction: 
Dear Florida law enforcement community, 
 
On April 4, 2025, U.S. District Judge Kathleen M. Williams issued an ex 
parte  temporary  restraining  order  prohibiting  the  Attorney  General,  the 
statewide prosecutor, the state attorneys, as well as โtheir officers, agents, 
employees,  attorneys,  and  any  persons  who  are  in  active  concern  or 
participation with themโ from enforcing Florida Statutes Sections 811.102 
and 811.103. See DE 28, Fla. Immigrant Coal. v. Uthmeier, No 1:25-cv-
21524. On April 18, the court extended her temporary restraining order 
through  April  29  and  clarified  verbally  that  her  order  covers  all  law 
enforcement officers in the State of Florida. And the court further instructed 
my office to notify you that all Florida law enforcement agencies at present 
must refrain from enforcing Sections 811.102 and 811.103. 
 
I must note my disagreement with this order. For reasons that my office has 
argued and will further outline in court, this clarification of Judge Williamsโ 
prior order is both wrong on the merits and overbroad on its scope. The 
Federal Rules of Civil Procedure empower the federal courts to enjoin 
parties, their officers, agents, employees, attorneys, and any persons who 
are in active concert or participation with those parties from taking certain 
actions. But independent law enforcement agencies are not parties in this 
case. At most, a district court may enjoin the law enforcement community 
when it is acting in concert or participating with the named defendants to 
enforce these statutes and, as my office will soon explain, the courtโs current 
injunction exceeds that equitable limitation. I should also note that while my 
office represents the current defendants named in this case, it does not 
represent nonparties like your law enforcement agencies. My office will 
nevertheless  continue  to  press  these  scope-of-relief  arguments  in  the 
district court and, as appropriate, in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 
Eleventh Circuit.  
 
That  said,  the  court  directed  my  office  to  notify  your  agencies  of  its 
clarification  that  law  enforcement  officers  should  take  no  steps  to 
enforce Sections 811.102 and 811.103, including through arrests or 
detentions based on suspected violations of those provisions. Please 
instruct  your  officers  and  agents  to  comply  with  Judge  Williamsโ 
directives.  
 
A copy of the temporary restraining order is attached below.  
 
(DE 57-2 (emphasis added).) Five days later, Uthmeier sent his follow-up April 23rd Letter, 
which is the subject of these show cause proceedings:  
Page 5 of 27 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 96   Entered on FLSD Docket 06/17/2025   Page 6 of 27
Good afternoon, 
 
I  write  to  provide  an  update  on  my  Friday,  April  18  letter.  In  that 
communication, I notified you that U.S. District Judge Kathleen M. Williams 
believed all law enforcement agencies in Florida were bound by an ex parte 
temporary restraining order she issued on April 4, 2025 in Fla. Immigrant 
Coal. v. Uthmeier, No 1:25-cv-21524, a case in which no law enforcement 
agencies are parties. I explained that I believed her after-the-fact expansion 
of her order to nonparties was wrong, and that my office would be arguing 
as much in short order. Today, my office filed a brief explaining why her 
order cannot possibly restrain Floridaโs law enforcement agencies from 
enforcing Florida Statutes Sections 811.102 and 811.103. We will continue 
to argue that positionโincluding on appeal as soon as possible. 
 
That said, I want to make clear what I expressed in my April 18 letter. Judge 
Williams ordered my office to notify you of the evolving scope of her order, 
and I did so. But I cannot prevent you from enforcing ยงยง 811.102 and 
811.103, where there remains no judicial order that properly restrains 
you from doing so. As set forth in the brief my office filed today, it is 
my  view  that  no  lawful,  legitimate  order  currently  impedes  your 
agencies from continuing to enforce Floridaโs new illegal entry and 
reentry laws. 
 
(DE 57-1 at 2 (first emphasis in the original; second emphasis added).)  
B. Show cause proceedings 
At the April 29, 2025 Status Conference, the Court expressed its view that 
language in the April 23rd Letterโparticularly Uthmeierโs statements, โI cannot prevent 
you from enforcing ยงยง 811.102 and 811.103, where there remains no judicial order 
that properly restrains you from doing soโ and โit is my view that no lawful, legitimate 
order currently impedes your agencies from continuing to enforce Floridaโs new illegal 
entry  and  reentry  lawsโโappeared  to  vitiate  the  notice  to  law  enforcement  that 
Uthmeier  gave  in  the  April  18th  Letter  and  that  contempt  proceedings  may  be 
warranted. (DE 71 at 23โ24.) Defendants argued that the April 23rd Letter merely set 
out AG Uthmeierโs litigating position as detailed in Defendantsโ brief filed that day. (Id. 
at 24โ25.) Because Uthmeierโs counsel urged the Court to give Uthmeier the benefit 
Page 6 of 27 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 96   Entered on FLSD Docket 06/17/2025   Page 7 of 27
of the doubt as to his intent regarding the April 23rd Letter, and to prevent any violations 
of the TRO by law enforcement the letter might occasion, the Court gave Uthmeier the 
opportunity to allay the Courtโs concern, and, at the request of Uthmeierโs counsel, 
took a brief recess. (Id. at 42.)  Uthmeierโs counsel returned, declined this opportunity, 
and asked the Court for a briefing schedule on show cause proceedings. (Id. at 43.) 
  As a result, the Court required Uthmeier to show cause why he should not be 
held in contempt or sanctioned for violating the TRO and scheduled a Show Cause 
Hearing for May 29, 2025. (DE 67 at 48โ49.) Uthmeier filed a Show Cause Response, 
asserting that he had not violated either of the two mandates contained within the April 
18th Order, because: 1) he had not enforced S.B. 4-C, and 2) he provided actual notice 
of the TRO to the bound law enforcement officers in his April 18th Letter. (DE 81 at 3.) 
Plaintiffs responded that โ[b]y informing law enforcement that there was no order 
prohibiting them from enforcing S.B. 4-C, the Attorney General effectively undid the 
notice the Court ordered him to provide and encouraged law enforcement to violate 
the Courtโs order[.]โ (DE 87 at 3.)  
C. Uthmeierโs public statements 
In the weeks between sending the April 23rd Letter and the May 29, 2025 Show 
Cause Hearing, Uthmeier posted several videos to his official public social media 
accountโthe same account he used to convey the contents of his lettersโshowing 
him speaking about this matter in multiple interviews.4 Several of his statements 
 
4 Federal Rule of Evidence 201 allows the Court to โtake judicial notice on its ownโ of any 
facts that are โnot subject to reasonable dispute becauseโ they โcan be accurately and 
readily determined from sources whose accuracy cannot reasonably be questioned.โ Fed. 
R. Evid. 201(b)โ(c). Courts nationwide have taken judicial notice of publicly accessible 
social media posts and other website content based on this rule. See e.g., Force v. 
Page 7 of 27 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 96   Entered on FLSD Docket 06/17/2025   Page 8 of 27
addressed his reaction to the Courtโs April 18th Order:5    
In a May 6, 2025 interview, Uthmeier made the following statements:  
Interviewer: So, youโre just trying to let cops arrest illegals in your state, 
youโve got another one of these activist judges trying to stop you, and now 
it sounds like sheโs threatening to throw you in jail. Do I have it right? 
  
Uthmeier: Thatโs right. This judge is considering whether or not to hold 
me in contempt. But I am not going to rubber stamp her order, Iโm not 
going to direct law enforcement to stand down on enforcing the Trump 
agenda and carrying out Floridaโs law. Hereโs the thing, thereโs not a 
single law enforcement agency as a party in front of the court in this case. 
And as a lawyer, the first day of law school, they tell you about separation 
of powers, they tell you that a judge canโt order people around who are not 
under the jurisdiction of the court. So Iโm not gonna do that, Iโm not going 
to bow down and withhold my oath.  
 
Interviewer: Iโm always curious to hear the logic behind a ruling like this. 
What is her logic for not allowing, for demanding that cops not arrest illegal 
 
Facebook, Inc., 934 F.3d 53, 59 n.5, 61 n.8 (2d Cir. 2019) (finding proper judicial notice 
of terms and conditions publicly available on Facebookโs website and of the fact that 
publicly available news articles contained certain information); 23-34 94th St. Grocery 
Corp. v. New York City Bd. Of Health, 685 F.3d 174, 183 n.7 (2d Cir. 2012) (taking judicial 
notice of the pictorial and written contents of a poster published on a publicly accessible 
website); Al-Ahmed v. Twitter, Inc., 603 F. Supp. 3d 857, 867, 869 (N.D. Cal. 2022) (taking 
judicial notice of the contents of plaintiffโs twitter posts and direct messages). While these 
cases deal with writings and photographs rather than videos, the Court sees no relevant 
difference between those mediums of communication. Additionally, here, the statements 
were made by Uthmeier, and he chose to post them on his official social media account, 
placing the accuracy of the contents even further outside of any reasonable dispute. See 
OโToole v. Northrop Grumman Corp., 499 F.3d 1218, 1224โ25 (10th Cir. 2007) (holding 
trial courtโs refusal to take judicial notice of information posted on defendantโs website 
was abuse of discretion, in part, because the fact that it was the defendantโs โown 
information[] contribute[d] to its indisputabilityโ). Therefore, the Court finds it appropriate 
to take judicial notice of Uthmeierโs statements posted to his official social media account. 
But the Court notes that it takes judicial notice of the statements for the fact that Uthmeier 
made them rather than for the truth of any assertions made therein. See Khoja v. Orexigen 
Therapeutics, Inc., 899 F.3d 988, 999 (9th Cir. 2018) (holding that the transcript of a 
corporate investor call was subject to judicial notice, but โ[j]ust because the document 
itself is susceptible to judicial notice does not mean that every assertion of fact within that 
document is judicially noticeable for its truthโ). 
5 For the sake of brevity, the Court includes only the relevant portions of Uthmeierโs 
interviews. However, the full interviews are viewable at the links provided below. 
Page 8 of 27 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 96   Entered on FLSD Docket 06/17/2025   Page 9 of 27
immigrants in the State of Florida. What is she saying? 
 
Uthmeier: Itโs clear that sheโs got concerns with the law. We will appeal her 
injunction up at the appellate level. But she wants the law enforcement 
officers to stop committing arrests, and the problem is the ACLU didnโt sue 
any law enforcement officers. So if they want to arrest people under the 
law, if they want to hand them over to ICE, if they want to help the Trump 
administration carry out detentions and deportations, they have the legal 
authority to do that and Iโm not going to stand in their way.6  
 
@AGJamesUthmeier,  X  (May  6,  2025,  8:57  PM)  (emphasis  added), 
https://x.com/AGJamesUthmeier/status/1919919529699791161.7  
In a May 8, 2025 interview, Uthmeier said the following: 
Uthmeier: But we do have a judge who is threatening to hold me in 
contempt because I wonโt follow an order she has to direct our law 
enforcement not to enforce a new law we passed earlier this year that 
says you canโt be illegally in the State of Florida. 
 
Interviewer: So, this is a judge, let me get this straight, because I want to 
make sure Iโm clear about this. This is a judge in Florida, who has decided 
that a law that was passed by the Florida legislature and signed into law by 
Governor  DeSantis,  that  law  enforcement  not  obeying  that  .  .  .  sheโs 
basically directing them not to obey that law? 
 
Uthmeier: [T]he interesting thing here is no law enforcement agency in the 
state has been sued. Theyโre not a defendant. So, sheโs issuing this order 
and saying you gotta tell them all to stand down. Iโm not gonna do that. 
First day in law school you learn, that, you know, judges have jurisdiction, 
and you canโt order someone around whoโs not properly before the court. 
So, Iโve said no. I mean, my argument in court is that Iโm not gonna 
waive  my  obligation,  I  took  an  oath  to  the  constitution,  I  respect 
separation of powers, I respect these independent law enforcement 
bodies and their prerogative to follow the law and they should do that. 
 
 
 
6 Uthmeier conflates arrests pursuant to 8 U.S.C. ยง 1357(g)(1), which allows state and 
local officers to enforce federal immigration laws through โ287(g) agreements,โ with 
arrests under S.B. 4-C made in contravention of this Courtโs Order. Any arrests made 
pursuant to a 287(g) agreement are not the subject of this litigation.  
7 In 2023, Twitter rebranded as X.  
Page 9 of 27 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 96   Entered on FLSD Docket 06/17/2025   Page 10 of 27
@AGJamesUthmeier,  X  (May  8,  2025,  1:00  PM)  (emphasis  added), 
https://x.com/AGJamesUthmeier/status/1920524094442975631.  
III.  LEGAL STANDARD 
โCourts have inherent power to enforce compliance with their lawful orders through 
civil contempt.โ S.E.C. v. Greenberg, 105 F. Supp. 3d 1342, 1352 (S.D. Fla. 2015) (citing 
Shillitani v. United States, 384 U.S. 364, 370 (1966)). Courts must be alert to the risks of 
abuse of contempt powers, for โ[u]nlike most areas of law, where a legislature defines 
both the sanctionable conduct and the penalty to be imposed, civil contempt proceedings 
leave the offended judge solely responsible for identifying, prosecuting, adjudicating, and 
sanctioning the contumacious conduct.โ Intโl Union, United Mine Workers of Am. v. 
Bagwell, 512 U.S. 821, 831 (1994). That said, the contempt power is a โnecessity: Courts 
independently must be vested with power to impose . . . submission to their lawful 
mandates[.]โ Id. (internal quotations omitted).   
Before a civil contempt finding can be made, the Court must establish by clear 
convincing evidence that the following threshold criteria are met: (1) the allegedly violated 
order was valid and lawful; (2) the order was clear and unambiguous; and (3) the alleged 
violator had the ability to comply with the order. F.T.C. v. Leshin, 618 F.3d 1221, 1232 
(11th Cir. 2010). Then, the ultimate โfinding of civil contempt must be based on clear and 
convincing evidence that [the] order was violated.โ Jove Engineering, Inc. v. I.R.S., 92 
Page 10 of 27 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 96   Entered on FLSD Docket 06/17/2025   Page 11 of 27
F.3d 1539, 1545 (11th Cir. 1996) (internal quotations omitted).89 Procedurally, once a 
prima  facie  showing  of  a  violation  is  made,  โthe  burden  then  shifts  to  the  alleged 
contemnor to produce evidence explaining his noncompliance at a show cause hearing.โ 
Leshin, 618 F.3d at 1232 (internal quotations omitted). The alleged violator may show 
 
8 Clear and convincing proof is โmore exacting than the preponderance of the evidence 
standard but, unlike criminal contempt, does not require proof beyond a reasonable 
doubt.โ Ga. Power Co. v. N.L.R.B., 484 F.3d 1288, 1291 (11th Cir. 2007) (internal 
quotations omitted).  
9 In the Show Cause Response and at the Show Cause Hearing, Uthmeier seemed to 
argue  that  layered  on  top  of  the  clear  and  convincing  standard,  the  United  States 
Supreme Court has created an additional hurdle which must be overcome before a 
contempt finding can be made (DE 81 at 7.) Under this โrigorous standard,โ Uthmeier 
says, โthe Court must find that โthere is no objectively reasonable basis for concluding 
that [Uthmeierโs] conduct might be lawful.โ (Id. (quoting Taggart v. Lorenzen, 587 U.S. 
554, 561 (2019)).) But Uthmeier misreads Taggart.   
In Taggart, the Court was interpreting two bankruptcy code provisions, which together 
allowed a bankruptcy court to hold creditors in civil contempt for violating a discharge 
order. Id. at 556. The Court was presented with two suggested standards for analyzing a 
possible contempt finding, a strict liability standard and a subjective standard. Id. Instead, 
the Taggart Court decided that โtraditional civil contempt principles apply straightforwardly 
to the bankruptcy discharge context[,]โ and applied an objective standard, which courts 
have long used to analyze civil contempt. Id. at 561. So, the Court was not announcing a 
new  standard  for  analyzing  civil  contempt,  as  Uthmeier  argues,  but  applying  well-
established civil contempt principles to the bankruptcy context. This is confirmed by the 
Eleventh  Circuitโs  continued  use  of  the  standard  described  in  Leshin  and  Jove 
Engineering in cases after Taggart. E.g. Peery v. City of Miami, 977 F.3d 1061, 1076โ77 
(11th Cir. 2020); OโNeal v. Allstate Indem. Co., No. 22-11120, 2023 WL 5624158, at *5 
(11th Cir. Aug. 31, 2023); United States v. Mayer, No. 20-10231, 2022 WL 203338, at *1 
(11th Cir. Jan. 24, 2022); F.T.C. v. Natโl Urological Grp., 786 F. Appโx 947, 954 (11th Cir. 
2019).  
The language that Uthmeier seizes on, dicta from an 1885 case, was part of the Courtโs 
discussion of the principle that โthose enjoined receive explicit notice of what conduct is 
outlawed before being held in civil contempt.โ Id. (quoting Schmidt v. Lessard, 414 U.S. 
473, 476 (1974) (holding that the injunction was too vague to provide notice of what 
conduct is outlawed); then citing Intโl Longshoreman Assโn v. Philadelphia Marine Trade 
Assโn, 389 U.S. 64, 76 (1967) (guiding that civil contempt cannot be โfounded upon a 
decree too vague to understandโ)). That principle is embodied in the current standardโs 
requirement that an order be clear and unambiguous to form the basis of contempt.

that he did not violate the court order or was excused from complying based on an inability 
to comply despite making all reasonable efforts. Chairs v. Burgess, 143 F.3d 1432, 1436

Whether conduct violates an order is an objective question. See Ga. Power Co., 
484 F.3d at 1291 (โOur focus in a civil contempt proceeding โis not on the subjective 
beliefs or intent of the alleged contemners in complying with the order, but whether in fact 
their  conduct  complied  with  the  order  at  issue.โโ)  (quoting Howard  Johnson  Co.  v. 
Khimani, 892 F.2d 1512, 1516 (11th Cir.1990)). Therefore, โthe absence of wilfulness is 
not a defense to a charge of civil contempt. Leshin, 618 F.3d at 1232 (citing McComb v. 
Jacksonville Paper Co., 336 U.S. 187, 1919 (1949)).

1.  The April 23rd Letter vitiated the actual notice given in the April 18th Letter 
   The only question is whether Uthmeierโs April 23rd Letter negated the notice he 
gave in the April 18th Letter, violating Defendantsโ obligation to โprovide actual notice of 
the TROโ to all law enforcement officer[s] with the power to enforce S.B. 4-C.โ (DE 49.) 
Answering this question requires some discussion about the purpose and meaning of the 
April 18th Order. See United States v. Christie Indus., Inc., 465 F.2d 1002, 1007 (3d Cir. 
1972) (โThe language of an injunction must be read in the light of the circumstances 
surrounding its entry: the relief sought by the moving party, the evidence produced at the 
hearing on the injunction, and the mischief that the injunction seeks to prevent.โ) (citations 
omitted).  
The Court entered the April 18th Order after hearing that law enforcement officers 
were making arrests pursuant to S.B. 4-C, despite the Courtโs issuance of a TRO pausing 
enforcement of the Statute. The clear purpose of the April 18th Order was to prevent any 
such future arrests; the actual notice requirement was designed to address any law 
enforcement personnel who might make an arrest pursuant to S.B. 4-C based on the 
Page 14 of 27

misapprehension that they were not bound by the TRO.  
โโ[A]ctual noticeโ is synonymous with knowledge.โ Rosebud LMS Inc. v. Adobe Sys. 
Inc., 812 F.3d 1070, 1074 (Fed. Cir. 2016) (quoting 58 Am.Jur.2d Notice ยง 4 (2015) 
(explaining that โ[a]ctual notice rests upon personal information or knowledgeโ and โstems 
from and means that the party has actual knowledge of [the] fact in question.โ)); see also 
John Wiley & Sons, Inc. v. Kirtsaeng, No. 08 Civ. 7834, 2009 WL 3817407, at *3 (S.D.N.Y 
Nov. 9, 2009) (โNotice is regarded as actual where the person charged with notice either 
knows the particular facts in question or is conscious of having the means to know 
them[.]โ). Consequently, what matters is what law enforcement officers are likely to 
understand from the information Uthmeier gives them. See e.g., Brody v. Vill. of Port 
Chester, 509 F. Supp. 2d 269, 284 (S.D.N.Y. 2007) (analyzing the possibility that the 
content of a notice of was insufficient to provide actual notice). A directive that Uthmeier 
provide actual notice is not satisfied by sending the TRO and initially informing law 
enforcement officers that they are bound, and then issuing subsequent statements that 
are likely to mislead law enforcement officers into believing they are not bound. This 
defeats actual notice. 
In a variety of ways, Uthmeierโs April 23rd Letter conveyed to law enforcement that 
they could and should disregard the April 18th Letterโs message that they were required 
by court order to cease enforcement of S.B. 4-C. In the opening sentences of the letter, 
Uthmeier recharacterized the April 18th Order as the Courtโs โbelie[f],โ rather than the 
Courtโs โorderโ that law enforcement officers were bound by the TRO. Compare (DE 57-
1 at 2), with (DE 57-2 at 2.) After telling the recipients that Defendants had filed a brief 
arguing that the Courtโs โafter-the-fact expansion of [its] orderโ was wrong, Uthmeier

Grievances, Formal Op. 199 (1940)). As Attorney General, Uthmeier also has other 
โimportant and far-ranging responsibilities, including the power to institute litigation on his 
own initiative. . . . [o]n behalf of the state[.]โ Fla. Carry, Inc. v. Univ. of N. Fla., 133 So. 3d 
966, 989 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 2013) (Makar, J., concurring) (alterations and internal 
quotations omitted).  
Uthmeierโs role endows him with a unique capacity to uphold or undermine the rule 
of law, and when he does the latter by violating a court order, the integrity of the legal 
system depends on his conduct being within the Courtโs remedial reach. See J.G.G, 2025 
WL 1119481, at *1 (โThe Constitution does not tolerate willful disobedience of judicial 
ordersโespecially by officials of a coordinate branch who have sworn an oath to uphold 
it. To permit such officials to freely โannul the judgments of the courts of the United Statesโ 
would not just โdestroy the rights acquired under those judgmentsโ; it would make โa 
solemn mockeryโ of โthe constitution itself. . . . So fatal a result must be deprecated by 
all.โโ) (quoting United States v. Peters, 9 U.S. (5 Cranch) 115, 136 (1809) (Marshall, C.J.)). 
The very cases Uthmeier cites to support the notion that his status somehow shields him 
from a contempt finding bolster this principle. E.g. Newman v. State of Ala., 683 F.2d 
1312,  1318  (11th  Cir.  1982)  (โWhile  a  federal  court  is  always  reluctant  to  coerce 
compliance with its decrees by incarcerating a state official, if that official is in contempt 
there can be no doubt of the courtโs authority to do soโ); In re Attorney General, 596 F.2d 
Page 22 of 27 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 96   Entered on FLSD Docket 06/17/2025   Page 23 of 27
at 64 (โ[W[e unequivocally affirm the principle that no person is above the lawโ).15  
Equally  important  is  the  lawโs  commitment  to  free  speech,  including  that  of 
government officials and anyone whose speech criticizes courts. โCriticism keeps us on 
our toes and helps us do a better job. . . . Courts . . . speak with the knowledge of their 
imperfections but also with a sense that they instill a fidelity to law that would be sorely 
missed in their absence.โ Abrego Garcia v. Noem, No. 25-1404, 2025 WL 1135112, at *2 
(4th Cir. Apr. 17, 2025). To be clear, the Court is unconcerned with Uthmeierโs criticism 
and disapproval of the Court and the Courtโs Order. But respect for the integrity of court 
orders is of paramount importance. Within the bounds of the local rules and professional 
rules of conduct,16 Uthmeier is free to broadcast his continued appeal of the Courtโs 
 
15 In re Attorney General featured a court order requiring the United States Attorney 
General to release to opposing litigants the names of confidential government informants 
and  the  Attorney  Generalโs  assertion  โthat  the  [courtโs]  failure  to  recognize  the 
[governmentโs claim of] privilege would adversely affect the entire law enforcement and 
intelligence-gathering apparatus of the United States.โ 596 F.2d at 64. Here, the Court 
issued a routine order to Defendants to give actual notice to a non-party who was bound 
by the Courtโs injunctive relief. This case is devoid of the features that created sensitive 
separation of powers concerns in In re Attorney General. Meanwhile, in Newman, the 
plaintiffs had failed to move the court to initiate contempt proceedings following the state 
official defendantsโ violations of an injunction, and the Eleventh Circuit repeatedly guided 
them that moving for contempt would have been the proper remedy to pursue. 683 F.2d 
at 1318โ20 (โIn this case the plaintiffs chose to ignore equityโs time-honored contempt 
procedure in their effort to obtain the Stateโs compliance with the . . . [consent] decree.โ).  
16 Florida Bar Rule of Professional Conduct 4-8.4(d) provides, in part, that โ[a] lawyer shall 
not . . . engage in conduct in connection with the practice of law that is prejudicial to the 
administration  of  justice,  including  to  knowingly,  or  through  callous  indifference, 
disparage, humiliate, or discriminate against litigants, jurors, witnesses, court personnel, 
or other lawyers on any basis.โ Rule 4-8.2(a) prohibits a lawyer from โmak[ing] a statement 
that the lawyer knows to be false or with reckless disregard as to its truth or falsity 
concerning the qualifications or integrity of a judge[.]โ Fla. Bar R. of Pro. Conduct 4-8.2(a). 
Rule 4-8.4(c) prohibits โengag[ing] in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit, or 
misrepresentation[.]โ Fla. Bar R. of Pro. Conduct 4-8.4(c). And finally, the Florida Bar Rule 
regulating  public  pretrial  statements  provides  that  โ[a]  lawyer  shall  not  make  an 
extrajudicial statement that a reasonable person would expect to be disseminated by 
means of public communication if the lawyer knows or reasonably should know that it will 
Page 23 of 27 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 96   Entered on FLSD Docket 06/17/2025   Page 24 of 27
injunction and his view that the Courtโs rulings are erroneous. However, when instructed 
to inform law enforcement that they are proscribed from enforcing an enjoined law, he 
may not tell them otherwise. 
B. Sanctions 
โDistrict  courts  have  broad  discretion  in  fashioning  civil  contempt  remedies.โ 
Howard Johnson, 892 F.2d at 1519 (citing United Mine Workers, 330 U.S. at 303โ04). 
But civil contempt sanctions must serve โeither or both of two purposes: to coerce the 
defendant into compliance with the courtโs order, and to compensate the complainant for 
losses sustained.โ In re McLean, 794 F.3d 1313, 1323 (11th Cir. 2015) (citations omitted). 
โA coercive contempt sanction comes with limitations; for instance, once a contemnorโs 
contumacious conduct has ceased or the contempt has been purged, no further sanctions 
are permissible.โ F.T.C. v. Leshin, 719 F.3d 1227, 1231 (11th Cir. 2013) (citation omitted), 
cert. denied, Leshin v. F.T.C., 571 U.S. 1126 (2014). In contrast, the Courtโs โdiscretion 
in  imposing  non-coercive  sanctions  is  particularly  broad  and  only  limited  by  the 
requirement that they be compensatory.โ Id. (quoting Howard Johnson, 892 F.2d at 1521). 
โThe measure of the courtโs power in civil contempt proceedings is determined by the 
requirements of full remedial relief.โ Id. (quoting McComb, 336 U.S. at 193).  
  At  the  Show  Cause  Hearing,  Plaintiffs  stated  that  their  priority  is  to  ensure 
Uthmeierโs statements do not result in harm to provisional class members in the form of 
arrests and detentions. Since the Court has not been made aware of any arrests or 
 
have a substantial likelihood of materially prejudicing an adjudicative proceeding due to 
its creation of an imminent and substantial detrimental effect on that proceeding.โ Fla. Bar 
R. of Pro. Conduct 4-3.6(a). The Southern District of Florida Local Rules incorporate 
these rules. S.D. Fla. L.R. 11.1(c).      
Page 24 of 27 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 96   Entered on FLSD Docket 06/17/2025   Page 25 of 27
detentions pursuant to S.B. 4-C since the April 18th Order, Plaintiffs have been spared the 
downstream costs and attorneysโ fees, such as those arising from monitoring cases and 
coordinating release.  
  The Court agrees the most critical remedial goal is ensuring that the original 
purpose of the April 18th Order, to prevent enforcement of S.B. 4-C, is fulfilled. Therefore, 
the Court will require Uthmeier to coordinate with the State Attorney Defendants and their 
law  enforcement  partners  to  file  bi-weekly  reports  detailing  whether  any  arrests, 
detentions, or law enforcement actions pursuant to S.B. 4-C have occurred, and if so, 
how many, when, and by which law enforcement agency. Further, if Defendants learn of 
any arrests pursuant to S.B. 4-C, Defendants must immediately file notice informing the 
Court. In the event this occurs, the Court will require Defendants to re-notice the arresting 
law  enforcement  agency  to  prevent  future  violations.17  These  sanctions  have  both 
coercive and compensatory elements. The bi-weekly reports are meant to shift the costs 
of  continued  monitoring  for  violative  law  enforcement  activityโmade  necessary  by 
Uthmeierโs contumacious conductโonto Uthmeier and away from Plaintiffs. The re-
noticing requirement is meant to bring Uthmeier into compliance with the April 18th Order, 
should harm result from his noncompliance. Finally, if Uthmeier does not comply with 
these remedial sanctions, the Court will consider further sanctions, including fines and 
fees to compensate Plaintiffs for costs of enforcing the Courtโs order. 
 
 
17 The Court will also require that the language in any notice be given to Plaintiffs and the 
Court for review before being sent to the law enforcement agency. 
Page 25 of 27 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 96   Entered on FLSD Docket 06/17/2025   Page 26 of 27
V.  CONCLUSION 
Over a century ago, author and sometime logician Lewis Carroll guided readers 
through the looking glass.18 Among the adventures there, we encounter a character who 
boasts of his mastery of words:  
โWhen I use a word,โ Humpty Dumpty said, in rather a scornful 
tone, โit means just what I choose it to meanโneither more 
nor less.โ 
 
โThe question is,โ said Alice, โwhether you can make words 
mean so many different things.โ19  
 
The answer then, as now, is no. Litigants cannot change the plain meaning of words as 
it suits them, especially when conveying a courtโs clear and unambiguous order. Fidelity 
to the rule of law can have no other meaning. 
Therefore, it is ORDERED AND ADJUDGED as follows: 
1.  The Court finds Uthmeier in civil contempt of the Courtโs April 18th Order (DE 
49)  requiring  Defendants  to  provide actual notice of the  TRO  to  any  law 
enforcement officer with power to enforce S.B. 4-C.  
2.  Uthmeier shall FILE BI-WEEKLY REPORTS detailing whether any arrests, 
detentions, or law enforcement actions pursuant to S.B. 4-C have occurred, 
and if so, how many, when, and by which law enforcement agency. The first 
report shall be filed on or before July 1, 2025. Further, If Defendants learn of 
any arrests pursuant to S.B. 4-C, Uthmeier shall file notice informing the Court 
of the details of the arrests immediately. Uthmeier may seek modification or 
 
18 Lewis Carroll, Through the Looking-Glass, and What Alice Found There (1871). 
19 Id. at 269โ70. 
Page 26 of 27 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 96   Entered on FLSD Docket 06/17/2025   Page 27 of 27
termination of this reporting requirement after six months.  
DONE AND ORDERED in Chambers in Miami, Florida, on this 17th day of June, 
2025.

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 81   Entered on FLSD Docket 05/12/2025   Page 1 of 20
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE  
SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA 
 
FLORIDA IMMIGRANT COALITION, et al.,   
   
  Plaintiffs,    
v.    
  No. 1:25-cv-21524-KMW 
JAMES UTHMEIER, in his official capacity as 
Attorney General for the State of Florida, et al.,  
 
  Defendants. 
 
 
DEFENDANT ATTORNEY GENERAL OF FLORIDAโS RESPONSE TO 
ORDER TO SHOW CAUSE 
 
   
Jesse Panuccio  
(Florida Bar No. 31401) 
Evan Ezray  
(Florida Bar No. 1008228) 
Jason Hilborn 
(Florida Bar No. 1008829)

401 East Las Olas Blvd., Suite 1200

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 81   Entered on FLSD Docket 05/12/2025   Page 2 of 20
This Court ordered the chief legal officer of the State of Florida, Attorney General James 
Uthmeier, to โshow cause why he should not be held in contempt or sanctioned for violating this 
Courtโsโ temporary restraining order (โTROโ).  DE 67 at 48 (citing DE 28, 49).  In the two orders 
comprising the TRO, the Court enjoined the Attorney General in two respects.  First, the Court 
ordered him not to enforce sections 811.102 and 811.103, Florida Statutes (โSB 4-Cโ).  See DE 28 
at 14 (โprohibiting โฆ enforcing SB 4-Cโ); DE 49 at 1 (โprohibited from enforcing SB 4-Cโ).  The 
Attorney General has not enforced those laws since the Court entered the TRO.  Second, the Court 
ordered the Attorney General to โprovide actual notice of the TROโ to thousands of non-partiesโ
namely, โany officer or other personnel within any municipal or county police department within 
Florida, the Florida Department of Law Enforcement, or the Florida Highway Patrol, and any other 
law enforcement officer with power to enforce SB4-C.โ  DE 49 at 1โ2.  The Attorney General 
provided such notice.  Having complied with the Courtโs TRO, there is no basis for contempt or 
sanctions. 
The Courtโs show-cause order points to the Attorney Generalโs April 23 letter, which the 
Court describes as โadvising [the non-parties], in part, that โno lawful, legitimate order currently 
impedes [the non-parties] from continuing to enforceโ S.B. 4-C.โ  DE 67 at 48 (partially quoting 
DE 57-1).  But the elided quote in the show-cause order does not fairly reflect the April 23 letter 
in context.  Pursuant to the Courtโs TRO, the Attorney General had previously sent a letter to all 
law enforcement in the stateโthousands of officersโalerting these non-parties for the first time 
to their inclusion in the Courtโs injunctive relief.  In that first letter, the Attorney General noted 
that he believes the Court erred by including non-parties in its order and that he would be further 
briefing the issue.  The Attorney General filed that brief on April 23, see DE 56, and then sent the 
April 23 letter updating the thousands of non-party officers who, despite being enjoined through 
1 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 81   Entered on FLSD Docket 05/12/2025   Page 3 of 20
these proceedings, are otherwise not receiving any notice about them.  In that letter, the Attorney 
General explained โ[his] viewโ of the law โ[a]s set forth in the brief [his] office filedโ in this Court.  
DE 57-1.   
None of this violated the only two clear commands in the TRO: that the Attorney General 
(i) shall not enforce SB 4-C, and (ii) shall provide notice of the TRO to thousands of non-party 
law enforcement officers.  The TRO did not prohibitโmuch less clearly prohibitโthe Attorney 
General from (i) holding a legal view contrary to the conclusions reached by this Court, (ii) filing 
a brief explaining his legal position, (iii) notifying others of the filing of that brief, or (iv) publicly 
explaining  the  position  or  reasoning  in  that  brief.    Interpreting  the  TRO  to  include  such 
prohibitions, and then basing a contempt finding on that interpretation, would violate the rule that 
contempt exists only when a party clearly violates a clear order.  Interpreting an order to prohibit 
a state attorney general from disagreeing with a federal orderโwhile following itโwould also be 
an  extraordinary,  first-of-its-kind  assertion  of  federal  judicial  power,  implicating  grave 
constitutional concerns.  See U.S. CONST. AMENDS. 1, 10. 
BACKGROUND 
  The named Defendants are the Attorney General of Florida, the statewide prosecutor, and 
each state judicial circuitโs independently elected state attorney.  On April 4, 2025, this Court 
entered  a  temporary  restraining  order  โprohibiting  Defendants  and  their  officers,  agents, 
employees, attorneys, and any person[s] who are in active concert or participation with them from 
enforcingโ SB 4-C.  DE 28 at 14.  After a hearing on April 18, 2025, the Court issued an order 
finding that the โTRO shall be interpreted to include,โ as โprohibited from enforcing SB 4-C,โ tens 
of thousands of non-partiesโnamely, โany officer or other personnel with any municipal or county 
police department within Florida, the Florida Department of Law Enforcement, or the Florida 
Highway Patrol, and any other law enforcement officer with power to enforce SB 4-C.โ  DE 49 at 
2 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 81   Entered on FLSD Docket 05/12/2025   Page 4 of 20
1.1  The April 18 order required Defendants to โprovide actual notice of the TROโ to their own 
โofficers, agents, employees, [and] attorneys,โ as well as the thousands of non-parties included in 
the order.  Id. at 2.  The Court also ordered supplemental briefing on โthe proper scope of the 
TRO/PI.โ  Id.  
  Complying with the Courtโs directive, the Attorney General immediately sent a letter to all 
law enforcement agencies in Florida (โApril 18 Letterโ) informing them of the TRO and this 
Courtโs โclarification that law enforcement officers should take no steps to enforce Sections 
811.102 and 811.103, including through arrests or detentions.โ  DE 57-2 at 2.  In that letter, the 
Attorney General also explained his position that the TRO โis both wrong on the merits and 
overbroad in its scope.โ  Id. at 1.  He noted that his office would โcontinue to press these scope-
of-relief arguments in the district court and, as appropriate, in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 
Eleventh Circuit.โ  Id. 
On April 23, 2025, the Attorney General filed his supplemental brief, in which he argued 
that the Court โlacks equitable authority to enjoinโ non-parties to the case and that the TRO is 
therefore โoverbroadโ and may only extend, at most, to non-party law enforcement officers who 
โaid and abetโ Defendants in violating the injunction.  DE 56 at 2, 15.  That same day, the Attorney 
General sent a follow-up letter (โApril 23 Letterโ) updating the law enforcement agencies that his 
office had filed the supplemental brief.  DE 57-1.  In that letter, the Attorney General reiterated 
that the Court interpreted the TRO to reach โall law enforcement agencies in Florida.โ  Id.  But he 
also explained the position โset forth in the brief [his] office filedโโi.e., that enjoining thousands 
of non-parties across the state is โwrongโ and therefore the order was not โlawful.โ  The Attorney 
 
1 As of 2024, municipal police departments in Florida employed 20,225 officers, and 
county sheriffs employed 23,407 officers.  See Fla. Dept. of L. Enforcement, Criminal Justice 
Agency Profile Report, https://www.   fdle.state.fl.us/C      JSTC/Publications/CJAP/Statewide-Ratios. 
3 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 81   Entered on FLSD Docket 05/12/2025   Page 5 of 20
General explained that he would โcontinue to argue that positionโ in Court.  Id.  The Attorney 
General explained his view that, under state law, he (as opposed to the Court) โcannot prevent 
[other law enforcement agencies] from enforcing ยงยง 811.102 and 811.103.โ  Id. 
On April 29, after the Attorney General sent the April 23 Letter, this Court entered an 
Omnibus Order providing the Courtโs reasoning for including thousands of non-party municipal 
and county law enforcement officers within the scope of its injunction.  DE 67 at 37โ47.  The 
Court  concluded  that  these  thousands  of  local  officersโthough  independently  elected  or 
appointedโare agents of the Attorney General, and he has โcontrolโ and โstructural authorityโ 
over them, id. at 41, because:  
โข  of the possibility of โremovalโ of state, county, or municipal officers under section 
908.107, Florida Statutes (despite the removal authority being vested solely in the 
Governor), id. at 39; 
โข  there are โmultiple posts on AG Uthmeierโs social media, directing state law 
enforcement agencies โฆ to act,โ id. at 39โ40; 
โข  the Attorney General is one member of the four-member Commission that controls 
the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the Florida Highway Patrol by 
majority vote, id. at 40โ41; and 
โข  the Attorney General may give โan official opinion and legal adviceโ that is โnot 
bindingโ on Florida officials or courts, id. at 41.2 
In that same Omnibus Order, which for the first time explained the Courtโs theory of the 
Attorney Generalโs โcontrolโ and โauthorityโ over every law enforcement officer in Florida, the 
Court ordered the Attorney General to โshow cause why he should not be held in contempt or 
sanctioned for violating the TRO (DE 28; DE 49) through sending his April 23, 2025 letter to law 
enforcement agencies in Florida.โ  Id. at 48.  The Court characterized the April 23 Letter as a 
โmisstatementโ and an โactive effort to counsel law enforcement.โ  Id. at 40 n.25. 
 
2 The Omnibus Order does not cite any state or federal case reaching this same conclusion 
regarding the scope of the Florida Attorney Generalโs authority.   
4 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 81   Entered on FLSD Docket 05/12/2025   Page 6 of 20
ARGUMENT 
A federal district court must exercise its contempt power with extreme caution.  As the 
Supreme Court has explained: 
[T]he contempt power โฆ is liable to abuse.  Unlike most areas of law, where a 
legislature defines both the sanctionable conduct and the penalty to be imposed, 
civil  contempt  proceedings  leave  the  offended  judge  solely  responsible  for 
identifying, prosecuting, adjudicating, and sanctioning the contumacious conduct.  
Contumacy often strikes at the most vulnerable and human qualities of a judgeโs 
temperament, and its fusion of legislative, executive, and judicial powers summons 
forth ... the prospect of the most tyrannical licentiousness. 
Intโl Union, United Mine Workers of Am. v. Bagwell, 512 U.S. 821, 831 (1994) (quotation marks 
and citations omitted).  Civil contempt is thus a โpotent weapon,โ Taggart v. Lorenzen, 587 U.S. 
554, 560 (2019), and when โit is founded upon a decree too vague to be understood, it can be a 
deadly one,โ Intโl Longshoremenโs Assโn, Local 1291 v. Phila. Marine Trade Assโn, 389 U.S. 64, 
76 (1967) (alteration omitted).  
To guard against the risks of judicial overreach, Rule 65 of the Federal Rules of Civil 
Procedure requires an injunction to โdescribe in reasonable detail โฆ the act or acts restrained or 
required.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 65(d)(1)(C).  โ[T]hose enjoinedโ must โreceive explicit notice of 
precisely what conduct is outlawedโ before they can be subject to contempt.  Schmidt v. Lessard, 
414 U.S. 473, 476 (1974).  Thus, an โinjunction must be framed so that those enjoined know 
exactly what conduct the court has prohibited and what steps they must take to conform their 
conduct to the law.โ  S.E.C. v. Smyth, 420 F.3d 1225, 1233 n.14 (11th Cir. 2005) (quoting Fla. 
Assโn of Rehab. Facilities, Inc. v. Fla. Depโt of Health and Rehab. Servs., 225 F.3d 1208, 1222โ23 
(11th Cir. 2000)).  To that end, courts have consistently held that a โperson enjoined by court order 
should only be required to look within the four corners of the injunction to determine what he must 
do or refrain from doing.โ  S.E.C. v. Goble, 682 F.3d 934, 952 (11th Cir. 2012) (quoting Hughey v. 
JMS Dev. Corp, 78 F.3d 1523, 1531 (11th Cir. 1996)); see, e.g., Monsanto Co. v. Haskel Trading, 
5 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 81   Entered on FLSD Docket 05/12/2025   Page 7 of 20
Inc., 13 F. Supp.2d 349, 363 (E.D.N.Y. 1998) (โThe clarity of the order must be such that it enables 
the enjoined party โto ascertain from the four comers of the order precisely what acts are 
forbidden.โโ (quoting Drywall Tapers & Pointers of Greater N.Y., Local 1974 v. Local 530 of 
Operative Plasterers & Cement Masons Intโl Assโn, 889 F.2d 389, 395 (2d Cir. 1989))).   
Under that standard, โcivil contempt โshould not be resorted to where there is [a] fair 
ground of doubt as to the wrongfulness of the defendantโs conduct.โโ  Taggart, 587 U.S. at 561 
(quoting Cal. Artificial Stone Paving Co. v. Molitor, 113 U.S. 609, 618 (1885)).  This โrigorousโ 
standard, see In re Roth, 935 F.3d 1270, 1278 (11th Cir. 2019), permits civil contempt only if โthere 
is no objectively reasonable basis for concluding that [the defendantโs] conduct might be lawful,โ 
Taggart, 587 U.S. at 561.  Or, said differently, civil contempt will not lie when there is โan 
objectively reasonable basis to believeโ that the courtโs order did not bar the alleged โconduct.โ  In 
re Grant-Carmack, No. 23-11817, 2024 WL 1433714, at *4 (11th Cir. Apr. 3, 2024).  Civil 
contempt is thus โunavailableโ and โinappropriateโ if there is a โfair ground of doubt as to whether 
the [courtโs] order barred [the partyโs] conduct.โ  Roth, 935 F.3d at 1278 (quotation marks omitted); 
see also Trade Well Intโl v. United Cent. Bank, 778 F.3d 620, 626 (7th Cir. 2015) (contempt requires 
โan unequivocal command which the party in contempt violatedโ (quoting Maรฑez v. Bridgestone 
Firestone  N. Am.  Tire,  LLC,  533  F.3d  578,  591  (7th  Cir.  2008))).    โ[A]ny  ambiguities  or 
uncertainties in โฆ a court order must be read in a light favorable to the person charged with 
contempt.โ  Project B.A.S.I.C. v. Kemp, 947 F.2d 11, 16 (1st Cir. 1991); see also Ford v. Kammerer, 
450 F.2d 279, 280 (3d Cir. 1971) (โ[A]mbiguities and omissions in orders redound to the benefit 
of the person charged with contempt.โ); Ga. Power Co. v. NLRB, 484 F.3d 1288, 1291 (11th Cir. 
2007) (same).   
6 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 81   Entered on FLSD Docket 05/12/2025   Page 8 of 20
This demanding standard precludes contempt here.  The TRO had one prohibitory element

I.  The April 23 Letter Did Not Violate the Temporary Restraining Order Because It Did 
Not Enforce SB 4-C.

2.  Nothing in the April 23 Letter comports with the common understanding of โenforce.โ  
That phrase in the TRO โmust be read and interpreted objectively.โ  United States v. Scruggs, No. 
2:07-cr-325, DE 34 at 22 (N.D. Ala. Feb. 29, 2008).  Indeed, โunbroken lines of authorityโ caution 
courts โto read court decrees to mean rather precisely what they say.โ  NBA Props., Inc. v. Gold, 
895 F.2d 30, 32 (1st Cir. 1990) (Breyer, J.).  Said otherwise, in โdetermining whether a party is in 
contempt of a court order, the order is subject to reasonable interpretation.โ  Riccard v. Prudential 
Ins. Co., 307 F.3d 1277, 1296 (11th Cir. 2002).  And in engaging in that reasonable interpretation, 
courts must โconstrue any ambiguities or uncertainties ... โin a light favorable to the person charged 
with contempt.โ  Ga. Power Co., 484 F.3d at 1291. 
To โenforceโ means to โgive force or effect to (a law, etc.).โ  Enforce, Blackโs Law 
Dictionary (12th ed. 2024); see also Enforce, Websterโs Third New International Dictionary (2002 
10 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 81   Entered on FLSD Docket 05/12/2025   Page 12 of 20
ed.) (โto put into force; to cause to take effect; give effect to esp. with vigor <laws>โ); e.g., 
Scruggs, No. 2:07-cr-325, DE 34 at 23 (looking to dictionary to define the scope of an injunction).  
Enforcement, in other words, โtypically involves compulsion or constraint.โ  K.P. v. LeBlanc, 627 
F.3d 115, 124 (5th Cir. 2010).  State officials thus โenforceโ a law when โthey clearly ... assisted 
or currently assist in giving effect to the contested law.โ  Free Speech Coal., Inc. v. Anderson, 119 
F.4th 732, 736 (10th Cir. 2024) (quotation marks and alteration omitted).  By contrast, state 
officials do not enforce the law by promulgating it, see Mi Familia Vota v. Abbott, 977 F.3d 461, 
467โ68 (5th Cir. 2020), advocating for it, see Support Working Animals, Inc. v. Governor of Fla., 
8 F.4th 1198, 1203โ04 (11th Cir. 2021), or issuing written opinions on its scope or effect, see Free 
Speech Coal., Inc. v. Anderson, 685 F. Supp. 3d 1299, 1304 (D. Utah 2023).   
The common thread running through these decisions is that commenting about a lawโ
even strongly, and even in legally relevant waysโdoes not enforce the law.  For example, in 
Southern Pacific Transp. Co. v. Brown, 651 F.2d 613 (1980), the Ninth Circuit held that the Oregon 
Attorney General did not โenforceโ an Oregon law by โadvis[ing] Oregon district attorneys to 
presume the [law] constitutionalโโeven if โhis opinion might be persuasiveโโbecause the 
Attorney General had no authority under state law to โcompel the district attorneys to prosecute or 
refrain from doing so.โ  Id. at 614โ15 (observing district attorneys could โreject[]โ the Attorney 
Generalโs โadviceโ). 
Here, then, the April 23 Letter did not enforce SB 4-C.  The Attorney General did not direct 
law enforcement officials to do anything.  Nor did he compel law enforcement officials to do 
anything.  See K.P., 627 F.3d at 124.  Rather, he explained his โview ... [a]s set forth in the brief 
[his] office filed.โ  DE 57-1.  That is not enforcement.  E.g., United States v. Abbott, 85 F.4th 328, 
335 (5th Cir. 2023) (โpublic statementsโ are not enforcement); Tex. Democratic Party v. Abbott,

5.  Any doubt on these issues must be resolved against a finding of contempt. 
First, the law is clear that โ[i]f there is a fair ground of doubt as to the wrongfulness of the 
defendantโs actions said to be in contempt, the District Court should not entertain the civil contempt

Reynolds, 204 F. 709, 726 (5th Cir. 1913).  Here, at a minimum, there is a fair reading of the April

to find contempt.  See Ga. Power Co., 484 F.3d at 1291 (a court may โmake a finding of civil

alleged contempt is clear and convincingโ).

generally Erie R. Co. v. Tompkins, 304 U.S. 64 (1938).  But the Court should still exercise restraint 
 
state law did not give the Attorney General authority to โcontrolโ law enforcement officials.  City 
of S. Miami v. Governor, 65 F.4th 631, 641โ42 (11th Cir. 2023).   
The Attorney General, in short, would have had no way to know, when he wrote the April

when opining on โdifficult questions of state law bearing on policy problems of substantial public

should be doubly true in matters of contempt: it is one thing for this federal Court to disagree with

Third, in analyzing contempt, the Court should not โignore the fact that a contempt sanction 
imposed on the Attorney General in his official capacity has greater public importance, with 
separation of power overtones, and warrants more sensitive judicial scrutiny than such a sanction 
imposed on an ordinary litigant.โ  In re Attorney Gen. of U. S., 596 F.2d 58, 64 (2d Cir. 1979).  An 
attorney general, after all, is โa public official who exercises powers entrusted to him by both the 
executive and legislative branches, with obligations to the judicial branch โฆ Courts accordingly 
owe him respect as an official and, absent an abuse of power or misuse of office, the most careful 
and reasoned treatment as party or as litigant.โ  Id.  
Fourth, federalism principles counsel against finding the Attorney General in contempt.  
Though federal courts no doubt possess broad equitable power, โappropriate consideration must 
be given to principles of federalism in determining the availability and scope of equitable relief.โ  
Rizzo v. Goode, 423 U.S. 362 (1976).  Federal courts are therefore โalways reluctantโ to exercise 
that power to find a โ[state] official in contempt,โ Newman v. Alabama, 683 F.2d 1312, 1318 (11th 
Cir. 1982)โespecially when doing so might interfere with the operation of state government.  
Indeed, โconsiderations of comity and federalism argue for the federal courtsโ avoiding whenever 
possible getting involved in delicate issues concerning the internal structure of state government.โ  
United Beverage Co. of S. Bend, Inc. v. Ind. Alcoholic Beverage Commโn, 760 F.2d 155, 160 (7th 
Cir. 1985).  โAs representative of the dominant partner in the necessary interplay between the two

II.  The April 23 Letter Did Not Violate the Temporary Restraining Order Because the 
Attorney General Provided Actual Notice of the Order to Law Enforcement.  
The TROโs second requirement was for the Attorney General to โprovide actual notice of 
the TROโ to local law enforcement.  DE 49 at 2.  The Attorney General did exactly that.  See DE 
57-2 at 1 (providing notice that โall Florida law enforcement agencies at present must refrain from 
enforcing Sections 811.102 and 811.103โ).  And in doing so, he was clear that law enforcement 
should โinstruct your officers and agents to comply with Judge Williamsโ directives.โ  Id. at 2.  
Nothing more was required to comply with the TRO. 
For three reasons, nothing in the April 23 Letter undid that compliance.  First, by April 23 
the Attorney General had complied with the TRO.  He was required to provide actual notice.  And 
he did it.  See Chairs v. Burgess, 143 F.3d 1432, 1436 (11th Cir. 1998) (โA person who attempts 
with reasonable diligence to comply with a court order should not be held in contempt.โ (alteration 
omitted) (quoting Newman v. Graddick, 740 F.2d 1513, 1525 (11th Cir. 1984)); Mercer v. Mitchell, 
908 F.2d 763, 787 n.11 (11th Cir. 1990) (same).   
Second, nothing in the April 23 Letter revoked the Attorney Generalโs prior notice.  To the 
contrary, the April 23 Letter reiterates the April 18 Letter.  It says: โall law enforcement agencies 
in Florida were bound by an ex parte temporary restraining order.โ  DE 57-1.  A fair reading of the 
April 23 Letter thus cannot be read to undo the notice issued on April 18.   
Third, the Attorney Generalโs criticism of the TRO did not undermine his notice.  To be 
sure, the Attorney General firmly disagrees with the TRO.  And the April 23 Letter shares the 
Attorney Generalโs view that the TRO was not proper.  But the Court required only notice; not 
notice shorn from critique.5
