17 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 81   Entered on FLSD Docket 05/12/2025   Page 19 of 20
CONCLUSION 
  For all these reasons, the Court should decline to hold the Attorney General of the State of 
Florida in contempt or issue any other sanction.  
 
                
Dated: May 12, 2025  Respectfully submitted, 
  s/ Jesse Panuccio   
  Jesse Panuccio  
  (Florida Bar No. 31401) 
Evan Ezray  
(Florida Bar No. 1008228) 
Jason Hilborn  
(Florida Bar No. 1008829) 
BOIES SCHILLER FLEXNER LLP 
401 East Las Olas Blvd., Suite 1200 
Fort Lauderdale, Florida 33301 
jpannucio@bsfllp.com 
 
Counsel for the Attorney General of the State 
of Florida for the Contempt Proceedings 
 
 
 
756 F.3d 1222, 1240 (11th Cir. 2014).  And so, for the same reasons the Court should not hold 
General Uthmeier in contempt, it also should not sanction him. 
18 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 81   Entered on FLSD Docket 05/12/2025   Page 20 of 20

documents.title: Omnibus Order
documents.text:
Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 67   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/29/2025   Page 1 of 49
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA 
CASE NO. 25-21524-CV-WILLIAMS 
 
FLORIDA IMMIGRANT COALITION, et al., 
 
Plaintiffs, 
 
v. 
 
JAMES UTHMEIER, et al., 
 
  Defendants. 
___________________________________/ 
 
OMNIBUS ORDER 
THIS MATTER is before the Court on Plaintiffsโ Motion for a Preliminary Injunction 
(DE 4) and Plaintiffsโ Motion for Class Certification (DE 5). Both Motions are fully briefed.1 
On April 18, 2025 and April 29, 2025, the Parties presented oral argument on the Motions 
before the Court (the โHearingsโ). (DE 48; DE 66.) For the reasons set forth below, the 
Motion  for  Preliminary  Injunction  (DE  4)  is  GRANTED  and  the  Motion  for  Class 
Certification (DE 5) is GRANTED IN PART AND DENIED IN PART.. 
I.  BACKGROUND  
On February 13, 2025, Florida Senate Bill 4-C (โS.B. 4-Cโ or the โStatuteโ) went 
into effect. (DE 1 ยถ 40.) S.B. 4-C creates two new state law offenses: โIllegal entry by 
adult unauthorized alien2 into this stateโ and โIllegal reentry of an adult unauthorized 
 
1 Defendants filed responses in opposition to both Motions (DE 40; DE 44), and Plaintiffs 
replied (DE 45; DE 46). 
2 The various statutes and cases discussed within this Order use a variety of terms, in 
additional to โalien,โ to describe a noncitizen or foreign national in the United States. See 
United States Citizenship and Immigration Services, Glossary (last visited Apr. 27, 2025) 
(defining an โAlienโ as โ[a]ny person not a citizen or national of the United Statesโ as 
defined  under  federal  law),  https://www.uscis.gov/tools/glossary.  For  clarity  and 
Page 1 of 49 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 67   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/29/2025   Page 2 of 49
alien.โ Fla. Stat. ยงยง 811.102โ.103. Section 811.102(1) prohibits any โunauthorized alien 
who is 18 years of age or olderโ3 from โknowingly enter[ing] or attempt[ing] to enterโ 
Florida โafter entering the United States by eluding or avoiding examination or inspection 
by immigration officersโ (โillegal entryโ). A first conviction for illegal entry is a first-degree 
misdemeanor, requiring a mandatory minimum sentence of nine monthsโ imprisonment, 
while  subsequent  convictions  are  felonies  with  escalating  mandatory  minimum 
sentences.  Fla.  Stat.  ยง  811.102(1)โ(3).  Under  subsection  811.103(1),  an  adult 
โunauthorized alienโ commits a third-degree felony, if they โenter[], attempt[] to enter, or 
[are]  at  any  time  found  inโ  Florida  after  โhaving  been  denied  admission,  excluded, 
deported, or removed or having departed the United States during the time an order of 
exclusion,  deportation,  or  removal  is  outstandingโ  (โillegal  reentryโ).  Fla.  Stat.  ยง 
811.103(1). Importantly, the scheme requires courts to presume that โno conditions of 
release can reasonably assure the presenceโ of any individual arrested under either 
provision and to order their detention without bond pending disposition of the case. Fla. 
Stat. ยงยง 811.102(5), 811.103(4).   
On April 2, 2025, Plaintiffs filed a Class Action Complaint (DE 1) (โComplaintโ), 
seeking injunctive relief barring enforcement of S.B. 4-C by state and local officials and a 
declaration  that  the  law  violates  the  United  States  Constitutionโs  Supremacy  and 
Commerce Clauses. (DE 1 at 17.) Plaintiffs include individuals V.V. and Y.M. (collectively 
 
consistency, when not quoting a source, the Court will use the phrase โnoncitizenโ 
throughout this Order. 
3 An โunauthorized alienโ is defined as anyone unlawfully present in the United States 
under the Immigration and Nationality Act and any other applicable federal law. Fla. Stat. 
ยง 811.101(2) (referencing Fla. Stat. ยง 908.111). 
Page 2 of 49 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 67   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/29/2025   Page 3 of 49
โIndividual Plaintiffsโ), who allege they are at risk of arrest and prosecution under the 
Statute,  and  two  grassroots  membership  organizations,  Farmworker  Association  of 
Florida,  Inc.  (โFWAFโ)  and  Florida  Immigrant  Coalition  (โFLICโ)  (collectively 
โOrganizational Plaintiffsโ), which support members who are similarly at risk. (Id. ยถยถ 8, 
11โ24, 26โ28.) On the same day, Plaintiffs sought class certification and a Temporary 
Restraining  Order  (โTROโ)  pausing  enforcement  of  S.B.  4-C  pending  the  Courtโs 
consideration of their request for a preliminary injunction. (DE 4; DE 5.) On April 4, 2025, 
the Court entered a TRO โprohibiting Defendants and their officers, agents, employees, 
attorneys, and any person who are in active concert or participation with them from 
enforcingโ S.B. 4-C for fourteen days. (DE 28 at 14.) Then, on April 18, 2025, the Court 
held a Hearing on whether to convert the TRO into a preliminary injunction. (DE 48.) At 
the conclusion of the Hearing, the Court set an additional Hearing for April 29, 2025 and 
extended the TRO until that time. The Court reconvened on April 29, 2025, to address 
the scope of injunctive relief. (DE 66.) Neither Party introduced evidence, so the Court 
relies on the Partiesโ written briefs, supplemented by their oral arguments at the Hearings.  
II.  LEGAL STANDARD 
Rule 65 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure authorizes courts to grant a 
preliminary injunction before final judgment in limited circumstances. The purpose of this 
injunctive relief is to โpreserve the status quo until the district court renders a meaningful 
decision on the merits.โ Schiavo ex rel. Schindler v. Schiavo, 403 F.3d 1223, 1231 (11th 
Cir. 2005) (citation omitted). To merit a preliminary injunction, Plaintiffs must show:  
(1) a substantial likelihood of success on the merits; (2) that the preliminary 
injunction is necessary to prevent irreparable injury; (3) that the threatened 
injury outweighs the harm the preliminary injunction would cause the other 
Page 3 of 49 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 67   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/29/2025   Page 4 of 49
litigant; and (4) that the preliminary injunction would not be averse to the 
public interest. 
 
Gissendaner v. Commโr, Ga. Depโt of Corr., 779 F.3d 1275, 1280 (11th Cir. 2015) (quoting 
Wellons v. Commโr, Ga. Depโt of Corr., 754 F.3d 1260, 1263 (11th Cir. 2014)). Plaintiffs 
โbear[] the burden of persuasion to clearly establish all four of these prerequisites.โ Wreal, 
LLC v. Amazon.com, Inc., 840 F.3d 1244, 1247 (11th Cir. 2016) (internal quotations 
omitted).  
A district court โmay provisionally certify a class for purposes of a preliminary 
injunction.โ Al Otro Lado, Inc. v. McAleenan, 423 F. Supp. 3d 848, 870 (S.D. Cal. 2019) 
(citing Meyer v. Portfolio Recovery Assoc., LLC, 707 F.3d 1036, 1043 (9th Cir. 2012)); 
see also Kaiser v. Cnty. of Sacramento, 780 F. Supp. 1309, 1312 (E.D. Cal. 1991) (โThe 
court has provisionally certified the class . . . pending modification or decertification should 
it become clear that the class is not maintainable. . . . Accordingly, the court may continue 
to grant injunctive relief on a class-wide basis.โ). However, Plaintiffs have the burden of 
โmeeting the threshold requirementsโ for class certification. Id.  
Rule 23(a) provides that a class may be certified only if: (1) the class is so 
numerous that joinder of all members is impracticable; (2) there are questions of law or 
fact common to the class; (3) the claims or defenses of the representative parties are 
typical of the claims or defenses of the class; and (4) the representative parties will fairly 
and adequately protect the interests of the class. Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a). โThese four 
prerequisites  of  Rule  23(a)  are  commonly  referred  to  as  โnumerosity,  commonality, 
typicality, and adequacy of representation.โโ Valley Drug Co. v. Geneva Pharms., Inc., 
350 F.3d 1181, 1188 (11th Cir. 2003). Further, the class action must fall into one of 
categories  enumerated  in  Rule  23(b).  Fed.  R.  Civ.  P.  23(b).  Plaintiffs  seek  class 
Page 4 of 49 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 67   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/29/2025   Page 5 of 49
certification under Rule 23(b)(2), which applies when โthe party opposing the class has 
acted or refused to act on grounds that apply generally to the class, so that final injunctive 
relief or corresponding declaratory relief is appropriate respecting the class as a whole[.]โ 
Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(2).  
As the Parties seeking class certification, Plaintiffs have โthe burden of proof,โ to 
show that the requirements of Rule 23 are โโin factโ satisfied.โ Brown v. Electrolux Home 
Prods., Inc., 817 F. 3d 1225, 1233 (11th Cir. 2016) (quoting Comcast Corp. v. Behrend, 
569 U.S. 27, 33 (2013)). Still, when determining whether the requirements for class 
certification are met, the Court โshould not consider the merits of [Plaintiffsโ] claim[s]โ 
except to the extent โnecessary to determine whether the requirements of Rule 23 will be 
satisfied.โ Williams v. Mohawk Indus., Inc., 568 F.3d 1350, 1358 (11th Cir. 2009) (citations 
omitted).  
III.  DISCUSSION 
The Court begins by addressing whether Plaintiffs have standing to seek their 
requested relief. See Wiand v. ATC Brokers Ltd., 96 F.4th 1303, 1311 (11th Cir. 2024) 
(noting that โstanding is a threshold jurisdictional questionโ and without establishing 
standing a โdistrict court [is] not empowered to reach any merits questionโ). Then, the 
Court will discuss the merits of the Motions. Finally, the Court will address the scope of 
injunctive relief. 
A. Plaintiffs have standing to bring this action. 
Plaintiffs who invoke โthe jurisdiction of a federal court bear[] the burden to show 
โ(1) an injury in fact, meaning an injury that is concrete and particularized, and actual or 
imminent, (2) a causal connection between the injury and the causal conduct, and (3) a 
Page 5 of 49 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 67   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/29/2025   Page 6 of 49
likelihood that the injury will be redressed by a favorable decision.โโ CAMP Legal Def. 
Fund, Inc. v. City of Atlanta, 451 F.3d 1257, 1269 (11th Cir. 2006) (quoting Granite State 
Outdoor Advert., Inc. v. City of Clearwater, 351 F.3d 1112, 1116 (11th Cir. 2003)).  
Plaintiffs must โsupport each element of standing with the manner and degree of 
evidence required at the successive stages of the litigation. At the preliminary injunction 
stage, then, the plaintiff must make a clear showing that she is likely to establish each 
element of standing.โ Murthy v. Missouri, 603 U.S. 43, 58 (2024) (citations and quotations 
omitted).4 โThe Supreme Court has been clear that standing in no way depends on the 
merits  of  the  plaintiffโs  claim  .  .  .  [s]o  [courts]  generally  assess  plaintiffsโ  standing 
assum[ing] that on the merits the plaintiffs would be successful in their claims.โ Polelle v. 
Fla. Secโy of State, 131 F.4th 1201, 1211 (11th Cir. 2025) (citations and quotations 
omitted). 
Defendants argue that all Plaintiffs lack standing. However, โ[w]here only injunctive 
relief is sought, only one plaintiff with standing is required.โ Martin v. Kemp, 341 F. Supp. 
3d 1326, 1333 (N.D. Ga. 2018); see also Greater Birmingham Ministries v. Secโy of State 
for State of Ala., 992 F.3d 1299, 1317 (11th Cir. 2021); Glassroth v. Moore, 335 F.3d 
1282, 1293 (11th Cir. 2003). Nonetheless, the Court analyzes standing for each individual 
and organizational Plaintiff and finds that all have standing.  
1.  Individual Plaintiffs 
 
4 The Court notes that, in Murthy, the Supreme Courtโs analysis reflected the fact that the 
parties had taken discovery. Murthy, 603 U.S. at 58 (โWhere, as here, the parties have 
taken discovery, the plaintiff cannot rest on โmere allegations,โ but must instead point to 
factual evidence.โ). Here, no discovery has been conducted. See also Rocky Mountain 
Gun Owners v. Polis, 121 F.4th 96, 108 (10th Cir. 2024) (โThe type of evidence that must 
be presented to make this showing depends on the necessity and status of discovery in 
the case.โ). 
Page 6 of 49 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 67   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/29/2025   Page 7 of 49
โInjury in fact reflects the statutory requirement that a person be adversely affected 
or aggrieved, and it serves to distinguish a person with a direct stake in the outcome of a 
litigationโeven though smallโfrom a person with a mere interest in the problem.โ Arcia 
v. Fla. Secโy of State, 772 F.3d 1335, 1340 (11th Cir. 2014) (quoting United States v. 
Students Challenging Regul. Agency Procs., 412 U.S. 669, 689 n.14 (1973)). An injury-
in-fact  is  โan  invasion  of  a  legally  protected  interest  which  is  (a)  concrete  and 
particularized and (b) actual or imminent, not conjectural or hypothetical[.]โ Lujan v. Defs. 
of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 560 (1992) (citations omitted). Defendants argue that Individual 
Plaintiffs have failed to offer concrete plans to exit or enter Florida and therefore fail to 
establish  an  injury.  Defendants  also  argue  that  Individual  Plaintiffs  have  no  legally 
protected interest in the conduct they seek to vindicate. The Court addresses each point 
in turn.  
a.  Concrete Injury 
V.V. is a FWAF member who was previously deported and last reentered the 
United States without inspection in 2014. (DE 1 ยถ 16.) She now lives in Immokalee, Florida 
with her husband and her four U.S. citizen children. (Id.) Plaintiff Y.M. is a FLIC member 
living in Florida, who entered the United States without inspection more than twenty years 
ago. (Id. ยถยถ 26โ27.) Y.M. leaves Florida twice a year with her minor U.S. citizen son who 
has a disability. (Id. ยถยถ 26, 28.) Individual Plaintiffs argue that they are at imminent risk of 
arrest and detention as they are subject to prosecution and imprisonment under S.B. 4-
C. (Id. ยถ 59.) It is irrelevant that they have not yet been arrested or prosecuted: โWhen an 
individual  is  subject  to  [the  threatened  enforcement  of  a  law],  an  actual  arrest, 
prosecution, or other enforcement action is not a prerequisite to challenging the law.โ 
Page 7 of 49 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 67   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/29/2025   Page 8 of 49
Susan B. Anthony List v. Driehaus, 573 U.S. 149, 158 (2014). โWhen the harm alleged is 
prospective, as it [is] here, a plaintiff can satisfy the injury-in-fact requirement by showing 
imminent harm. While the threatened future injury cannot be merely hypothetical or 
conjectural, probabilistic harm is enough.โ Arcia, 772 F.3d at 1341 (citations omitted).  
Plaintiff V.V., whose prospective prosecution would fall under S.B. 4-Cโs illegal 
reentry provision, need not allege any travel plans. Under that provision, V.V. is subject 
to arrest, detention, and prosecution if she โis at any time found in this state.โ Fla. Stat. ยง 
811.103(1). Therefore, her affidavit attesting to her prior deportation, reentry without 
inspection, and current residence in Florida, is sufficient to demonstrate a concrete injury. 
Plaintiff Y.M. has attested that she leaves the state twice a year and intends to continue 
doing so. Defendants characterize this testimony as the type of โโsome dayโ intentionsโ 
disavowed by the Supreme Court in Lujan. However, in Lujan, the plaintiffsโwho alleged 
their injury was based on their hope to one day return to Sri Lanka to view endangered 
speciesโtestified that they โhad no current plansโ to return, saying, โ[n]ot next year, I will 
say. In the future.โ Lujan, 504 U.S. at 564. Those allegations are in stark contrast to Y.M.โs 
testimony that she intends to travel in and out of state multiple times this year.5 See also 
Fla.  State  Conf.  of  N.A.A.C.P.  v.  Browning,  522  F.3d  1153,  1161  (11th  Cir.  2008) 
(โImmediacy requires only that the anticipated injury occur with some fixed period of time 
in the future, not that it happen in the colloquial sense of soon or precisely within a certain 
number of days, weeks, or months.โ).  
 
5 It is worth noting that nothing in standing jurisprudence โrequires a plaintiff who wishes 
to challenge the constitutionality of a law to confess that he will in fact violate that law.โ 
Susan B. Anthony List, 573 U.S. at 163. 
 
Page 8 of 49 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 67   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/29/2025   Page 9 of 49
Other courts have found that a plaintiff has โsuffered an injury in fact [when] sheโs 
established โa realistic danger of sustaining direct injuryโ from โthe statuteโs operation or 
enforcement.โโ Farmworker Assโn of Fla., Inc., 734 F. Supp. 3d at 1321 (quoting Ga. 
Latino All. for Hum. Rts. v. Governor of Ga., 691 F.3d 1250, 1257 (11th Cir. 2012) 
(โGLAHRโ)). Law enforcement agencies in Florida have already made numerous arrests 
pursuant to S.B. 4-Cโboth before and after the Courtโs entry of the TRO in this matterโ
which the Court finds evinces a realistic probability that Individual Plaintiffs could be 
subject to arrest and prosecution under S.B. 4-C.  
b.  Legally Protected Interest 
Defendantsโ argument that Plaintiffs have no legally protected interest is based on 
a misinterpretation of the right Plaintiffs seek to vindicate. Rather than seeking to drive 
without licenses, work without legal authorization, or seek to obtain transportation in 
violation of federal and state law, as Defendants contend, Plaintiffs simply wish not to be 
arrested and prosecuted under a law that violates constitutional principles of federalism. 
Numerous other federal courts have recognized this right as a legally protected interest. 
See GLAHR, 691 F.3d 1257โ62; Farmworker Assโn of Fla., 734 F. Supp. 3d at 1321โ29; 
see also Polelle, 131 F.4th at 1212 (โ[P]laintiffs allege a legally protected interest when 
they meet the โlow barโ of pointing to some arguable or colorable federal or constitutional 
interest.โ).  
2.  Organizational Plaintiffs 
โAn organization can establish Article III standing either โthrough its members [or] 
. . . through its own injury in fact.โโ City of S. Mia. v. Governor, 65 F.4th 631, 637 (11th 
Cir. 2023) (quoting Ga. Assโn of Latino Elected Offs., v. Gwinnett Cnty. Bd. of Registration 
Page 9 of 49 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 67   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/29/2025   Page 10 of 49
& Elections, 36 F.4th 1100, 1114 (11th Cir. 2022)). As an initial matter, it is necessary to 
clarify Plaintiffsโ theory of standing: FWAF does not assert organizational standing based 
on diversion of resources and neither FWAF nor FLIC seek to assert the rights of third 
parties. Accordingly, to the extent Defendantsโ briefing covers such arguments, they will 
not be addressed.  
โTo establish associational standing, an organization must prove that its members 
โwould otherwise have standing to sue in their own right.โโ Jacobson v. Fla. Secโy of State, 
974 F.3d 1236, 1249 (11th Cir. 2020) (citations omitted). When analyzing associational 
standing, โplaintiff-organizations [are required] to make specific allegations establishing 
that at least one identified member had suffered or would suffer harm.โ Summers v. Earth 
Island Inst., 555 U.S. 488, 498 (2009). V.V. is a member of both FWAF and FLIC, and 
Y.M. is a member of FLIC. (DE 4-3 ยถยถ 15, 19.) As discussed, supra, Individual Plaintiffs 
have standing to sue in their own right. Furthermore, both organizations allege that they 
have membersโbeyond Individual Plaintiffsโwho would suffer harm if S.B. 4-C is not 
enjoined. Accordingly, the Court finds that the organizational plaintiffs have standing 
under the theory of associational standing.6  
3.  Traceability & Redressability 
โThe latter two requirements [of standing]โtraceability and redressabilityโoften 
travel together, and where, as here, a plaintiff has sued to enjoin a government official 
from enforcing a law, he must show, at the very least, that the official has the authority to 
enforce the particular provision that he has challenged, such that an injunction prohibiting 
 
6 Because the Court finds the Organizational Plaintiffs each have associational standing, 
it does not need to reach Plaintiffsโ arguments that FLIC also has standing under a 
diversion of resources theory.  
Page 10 of 49 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 67   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/29/2025   Page 11 of 49
enforcement would be effectual.โ Support Working Animals, Inc. v. Governor of Fla., 8 
F.4th 1198, 1201 (11th Cir. 2021). Put another way, โ[w]hen traceability and redressability 
are at stake, the key questions are who caused the injury and how it can be remedied.โ 
City of S. Mia., 65 F.4th at 640.   
To determine redressability, the Court focuses โon whether the injury that a plaintiff 
alleges is likely to be redressed through the litigation.โ Sprint Commcโns Co., L.P. v. APCC 
Servs., Inc., 554 U.S. 269, 287 (2008) (emphasis in original). Defendants argue that 
Plaintiffs lack standing to sue all state attorneys but raise no arguments related to 
standing as to the Attorney General or Statewide Prosecutor. The Court, in its prior order, 
found Plaintiffs had standing to sue all Defendants. In this order, the Court only addresses 
traceability and redressability as to the state attorneys.  
The injuries facing Plaintiffs are arrest and prosecution under S.B. 4-C. State 
attorneys are state officials charged with โprosecut[ing] or defend[ing] on behalf of the 
state all suits, applications, or motions, civil or criminal, in which the state is a party[.]โ7 
Fla.  Stat.  ยง  27.02  (emphasis  added).  State  attorneys  are  tasked  with  prosecuting 
violations of S.B. 4-C and Defendants do not dispute this delegation of responsibility. 
Instead, they argue that V.V. only has standing against the state attorney who could 
prosecute her in the city she resides in, and that Y.M. would only have standing against 
the state attorney assigned to the jurisdiction where she will reenter the state. These 
geographic strictures fail for several reasons. First, V.V. would be subject to prosecution 
anywhere and โany timeโ she is โfound [within the] state.โ Fla. Stat. ยง 811.103(1). Second, 
because V.V. is a farmworker, she travels around the state and out of state for such work. 
 
7 There are certain exceptions to this duty, none of which are relevant here.  
Page 11 of 49 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 67   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/29/2025   Page 12 of 49
(DE 4-4 ยถ 8.) Y.M. does the same for personal travel. (DE 4-5 ยถ 7.) Neither must detail 
their precise paths of travel through each state attorneyโs jurisdiction to support standing. 
See Drewniak v. U.S. Customs and Border Prot., 554 F. Supp. 3d 348, 363โ64 (D.N.H. 
2021) (Plaintiffsโ allegation that he would continue using a main intrastate highway to 
travel between two areas in New Hampshire created a sufficient risk of being stopped at 
a random CBP checkpoint for Article III standing, despite Plaintiff not alleging a precise 
route or timing of travel); see also Babbitt v. United Farm Workers Nat. Union, 442 U.S. 
289, 298 (1979) (โWhen the plaintiff has alleged an intention to engage in a course of 
conduct arguably affected with a constitutional interest, but proscribed by a statute, and 
there exists a credible threat of prosecution thereunder, he should not be required to await 
and undergo a criminal prosecution as the sole means of seeking relief.โ) (internal 
quotations omitted). Defendantsโ arguments assume a rigidity of travel that does not 
comport with the pleadings, case authority, or the realities of modern movement.   
Because the state attorneysโ authority to prosecute violations of S.B. 4-C would 
cause Plaintiffsโ injuries, enjoining them from doing so will directly redress those injuries. 
Put another way, Plaintiffsโ requested reliefโan order declaring the entry and reentry 
provisions of S.B. 4-C to be unlawful and enjoining the state attorneys from prosecuting 
people under those provisionsโwill directly resolve Plaintiffsโ reasonable fear that the 
challenged law will be enforced against them or their members by those Defendants. 
Given that Plaintiffs have standing, the Court will address the remainder of the factors 
governing their request for a preliminary injunction.8  
 
8 Defendants advance a final threshold argument, namely that Plaintiffs lack a โcause of 
actionโ for their suit because the Supremacy Clause does not provide one and the 
Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) displaces equitable relief through its own detailed 
Page 12 of 49 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 67   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/29/2025   Page 13 of 49
B. Plaintiffs have met the criteria for issuance of a preliminary injunction. 
As stated above, to succeed on a motion for preliminary injunction Plaintiffs must 
show: โ(1) a substantial likelihood of success on the merits; (2) that the preliminary 
injunction  is  necessary  to  prevent  irreparable  injury;  (3)  that  the  threatened  injury 
outweighs the harm the preliminary injunction would cause the other litigant; and (4) that 
the preliminary injunction would not be averse to the public interest.โ Gissendaner, 779 
F.3d at 1280 (citation omitted). The Court addresses each requirement in turn.  
1.  Likelihood of success on the merits 
Plaintiffs argue S.B. 4-C violates the Supremacy Clause by creating a statutory 
scheme in an area exclusively reserved for the federal government that conflicts with 
 
remedial scheme. (DE 40 at 8โ11) (relying on Armstrong v. Exceptional Child Ctr., Inc., 
575 U.S. 320, 326โ29 (2015)). First, Plaintiffs have never advanced the theory that their 
suit is pursuant to a โcause of actionโ granted by the Supremacy Clauseโinstead, they 
are invoking the Courtโs equitable jurisdiction pursuant to Ex parte Young. See Armstong, 
575 U.S. at 325, 326 (reiterating the well-accepted principles that the Supremacy Clause 
โcertainly does not create a cause of actionโ but that, โas [the Supreme Court] has long 
recognized, if an individual claims federal law immunizes him from state regulation, the 
court may issue an injunction upon finding the state regulatory actions preemptedโ) (citing 
Ex parte Young, 209 U.S. 123, 155โ156 (1908)).  
Second, just days ago, Judge Ruiz squarely rejected Defendantsโ argument that the INA 
displaces equitable relief in a thorough, well-reasoned analysis in a case involving a 
preemption challenge to enforcement of another state immigration scheme. Farmworker 
Assโn of Fla., Inc. v. Uthmeier, No. 23-CV-22655 (S.D. Fla. Apr. 17, 2025), DE 137 at 5โ
14. The Court will not rehash all the issues with Defendantsโ position in the same depth 
here. In short, however, the fact that the INA delegates general โadministration and 
enforcementโ to the Secretary of Homeland Security, see 8 U.S.C. ยง 1103(a)(1), and 
prosecution of federal entry and reentry offenses to United States attorneys, see 8 U.S.C. 
ยง 1329, in no way demonstrates a Congressional intent to displace equitable relief when 
a party does not seek to enforce the INA, but seeks to avoid prosecution under a state 
law preempted by the INA. See Farmworker Assโn of Fla., Inc., No. 23-CV-22655, DE 137 
at 10โ11 (concluding the INA does not contain a โsole remedy,โ foreclosing equitable 
relief). Therefore, Plaintiffsโ ability to invoke equitable jurisdiction under Ex Parte Young 
remains intact.

existing federal immigration law and its enforcement. (DE 4 at 5); see U.S. Const. art. VI 
(making federal law the โsupreme Law of the Landโ). In other words, they argue that S.B. 
4-C is โfield preemptedโ and โconflict preemptedโ by federal immigration law governing 
entry, reentry, and continued presence of noncitizens. (Id. at 6, 11.) Plaintiffs further 
contend that S.B. 4-C runs afoul of the Commerce Clauseโs implicit limitation on statesโ 
power to restrict the interstate movement of people. (Id. at 14); see U.S. Const. art. I, ยง 
8, cl. 3 (giving Congress the power to โregulate Commerce with foreign Nations, and 
among the several States, and with the Indian Tribesโ). For the reasons set forth below, 
the Court agrees that, at this early stage, Plaintiffs have shown they are likely to succeed 
on the merits.   
a.  Supremacy Clause  
When analyzing whether a state law is preempted by a federal scheme, โthe 
purpose of Congress is the ultimate touchstone.โ Marrache v. Bacardi U.S.A., Inc., 17 
F.4th 1084, 1094 (11th Cir. 2021) (quoting Wyeth v. Levine, 555 U.S. 555, 565 (2009)). 
Congressional intent to preempt state law is most readily discernable when it is โexplicitly 
stated in the [federal] statuteโs language.โ Cipollone v. Liggett Grp., Inc., 505 U.S. 504, 
516  (1992)  (describing  express  preemption);  see  also  Marrache,  17  F.4th  at  1094 
(describing an โexpress statement on preemptionโ as preferrable).9 However, state law 
can also be โimpliedly preemptedโ by federal law in cases of conflict preemption and field 
preemption. Marrache, 17 F.4th at 1094.  
Conflict preemption occurs โwhere it is impossible for a private party to comply with 
both state and federal laws . . . [or] the challenged state law stands as an obstacle to the 
 
9 Plaintiffs do not argue any such explicit statutory language is present here.

accomplishment and execution of the full purposes and objectives of Congress.โ Crosby 
v.  Natโl  Foreign  Trade  Council,  520  U.S.  363,  373โ74  (2000)  (internal  citation  and 
quotations omitted). A state law is field preempted when it regulates conduct โin a field 
that Congress, acting within its proper authority, has determined must be regulated by its 
exclusive governance.โ Arizona v. United States, 567 U.S. 387, 399 (2012) (holding the 
field of noncitizen registration is field preempted). โThe categories of preemption are not 
rigidly distinct . . . [and] field pre-emption may be understood as a species of conflict pre-
emption.โ Natโl Assโn of State Utility Consumer Advocs. v. Fed. Commcโn Commโn, 457 
F.3d 1238, 1252 (11th Cir. 2006) (quoting Crosby, 530 U.S. at 372 n.6). Of course, the 
Court will not assume Congress intended to supersede the historic police powers of the 
States โin the absence of persuasive reasonsโeither that the nature of the regulated 
subject matter permits no other conclusion, or that the Congress has unmistakably so 
ordained.โ Marrache, 17 F.4th at 1095 (quoting Natโl Assโn of State Util. Consumer 
Advocs., 457 F.3d at 1252). However, both the nature of the subject matter and the 
extensive scheme of regulation authored by Congress over decades support the Courtโs 
analysis set out below.  
i.  Field Preemption 
Courts may infer an intent to displace state law from a โframework of regulation so 
pervasive that Congress left no room for the States to supplement it, or where there is a 
federal  interest  so  dominant  that  the  federal  system  will  be  assumed  to  preclude 
enforcement of state laws on the same subject.โ Arizona, 567 U.S. at 399 (alterations 
accepted and internal quotations omitted).

โFor nearly 150 years, the Supreme Court [and other federal courts have] held that 
the power to control immigrationโthe entry, admission, and removal of noncitizensโis 
exclusively a federal power.โ United States v. Texas, 97 F.4th 268, 278โ79 (5th Cir. 2024). 
Most recently, courts established that federal law preempts any state scheme in the fields 
of noncitizen registration and the transport and movement of noncitizens, both closely 
related to illegal entry and reentry. In fact, in those cases, courts grouped federal entry 
and reentry provisions together with the other fields as part of โthe larger context of federal 
statutes criminalizing the acts undertaken by aliens and those who assist them in coming 
to, or remaining within, the United States.โ GLAHR, 691 F.3d at 1264; Arizona, 567 U.S. 
at 395โ96 (describing the INAs โextensive and complexโ scheme as not just covering 
noncitizen  registration,  but  also  โwho  may  not  be  admitted  to  the  United  States,โ 
โ[u]nlawful entry and unlawful reentry into the country,โ and โwhich aliens may be removed 
from the United Statesโ) (citing 8 U.S.C. ยงยง 1325, 1326, the federal entry and reentry 
provisions S.B. 4-C is modeled after). 
First, in Arizona, the Supreme Court held that the field of noncitizen registration 
was fully occupied by the comprehensive immigration scheme created in 1952 by the 
Immigration and Nationality Act (โINAโ), 8 U.S.C. ยง 1101, et seq. 567 U.S. at 401โ02; see 
also Patel v. Garland, 596 U.S. 328, 331 (2022) (โCongress has comprehensively detailed 
the rules by which noncitizens may enter and live in the United States. When noncitizens 
violate those rules, Congress has provided procedures for their removal.โ). The Supreme 
Court found that the noncitizen registration provisions within this scheme โprovide a full 
set of standards . . . including the punishment for noncompliance. It was designed as a 
โharmonious whole.โโ Id. at 401 (quoting Hines v. Davidowitz, 312 U.S. 52, 72 (1941)).

Further, the Court noted the importance to U.S. foreign relations of having โa single 
sovereign responsible for maintaining a comprehensive and unified systemโ to track 
noncitizens. Id. at 401โ02. โIt is fundamental that foreign countries concerned about the 
status, safety, and security of their nationals in the United States must be able to confer 
and communicate on this subject with one national sovereign, not the 50 separate States.โ 
Id. at 395; see also Hines, 312 U.S. at 64 (โOne of the most important and delicate of all 
international relationships, recognized immemorially as a responsibility of government, 
has to do with the protection of the just rights of a country's own nationals when those 
nationals are in another country.โ). 
The Eleventh, Ninth, and Fourth Circuits found these principles apply with equal 
force to the federal governmentโs regulation of noncitizen transport and movement. See, 
e.g.,  GLAHR,  691  F.3d  at  1263โ64  (holding  the  โINA  provides  a  comprehensive 
framework to penalize the transportation, concealment, and inducement of unlawfully 
present aliens,โ preempting a Georgia state law regulating the same conduct); United 
States v. Alabama, 691 F.3d 1269, 1287 (11th Cir. 2012) (agreeing with GLAHR and 
holding Alabamaโs similar law was field preempted); Valle del Sol Inc. v. Whiting, 732 
F.3d 1006, 1026 (9th Cir. 2013) (same for Arizona law); United States v. South Carolina, 
720 F.3d 518, 530โ32 (4th Cir. 2013) (same for South Carolina law). The INA creates 
prohibitions for offenses relating to noncitizen transport and movement, specifies criminal 
and  civil  penalties,  and  delegates  enforcement  of  the  provisions  to  United  States 
attorneys. GLAHR, 691 F.3d at 1263โ64 (citing 8 U.S.C. ยงยง 1324, 1329). โLike the federal 
registration scheme addressed in Arizona, [this is] a โfull set of standardsโ to govern the 
unlawful transport and movement of aliens.โ Id. at 1264 (quoting Arizona, 567 U.S. at

401). Further, restricting the movement of noncitizens into and within the United States 
by criminalizing those who transport, conceal, or encourage their movement impacts โthe 
status, safety, and security of [foreign] nationals in the United Statesโ such that foreign 
countries โmust be able to confer and communicate on this subject with one national 
sovereign, not the 50 separate states.โ Whiting, 723 F.3d at 1023โ24.        
Federal regulation of entry and reentry share both traitsโcomprehensiveness and 
impact on sensitive foreign relations interestsโwith that of noncitizen registration and 
noncitizen transportation and movement. The INA defines and prohibits illegal entry and 
reentry and creates specific civil and criminal penalties for violations. 8 U.S.C. ยงยง 1325 
(entry),  1326  (reentry).  The  reentry  provision  in  particular  recognizes  the  need  for 
nuanced immigration decisions. For instance, it provides differing penalties for those 
reentering without prior convictions and those reentering after โcommission of three or 
more  misdemeanorsโ  involving  specified  offenses  or  โan  aggravated  felony,โ  those 
reentering after being excluded from the United States after committing terrorist activities, 
and those reentering after being removed prior to completion of a prison sentence. 8 
U.S.C. ยง 1326(b)(1)โ(4), (c). And like the provisions regarding noncitizen transportation 
addressed in GLAHR, the INA โconfin[es] the prosecution of [illegal entry and reentry] to 
federal courtโ and โlimit[s] the power to pursue those cases to the appropriate United 
States Attorney.โ GLAHR, 691 F.3d at 1265; see 8 U.S.C. ยง 1329. Together, these 
provisions provide โa full set of standards governing [entry and reentry], including the 
punishment for noncomplianceโ and methods of enforcement. Arizona, 567 U.S. at 401. 
They were โdesigned as a harmonious whole . . . reflecting a Congressional decision to 
foreclose any state regulation in the area.โ Id.

Defendants resist the great weight of this authority by positing hollow distinctions

States, and with the Indian Tribes.โ U.S. Const. art. I, ยง 8, cl 3; see (DE 4 at 14). That 
power  โencompasses  the  movement  in  interstate  commerce  of  persons  as  well  as 
commodities.โ United States v. Guest, 383 U.S. 745, 758โ59 (1966); see also Edwards 
v.  California,  314  U.S.  160,  172  (1941)  (โ[I]t  is  settled  beyond  question  that  the 
transportation of persons is โcommerce,โ within the meaning ofโ the Commerce Clause.). 
Implicit in congressional power to regulate interstate commerce is an โimplicit or โdormantโ 
limitation on the authority of the States to enact legislation affecting interstate commerce.โ 
Fla. Transp. Servs., Inc. v. Miami-Dade Cnty., 703 F.3d 1230, 1243 (11th Cir. 2012). 
When a scheme โdirectly regulates or discriminates against interstate commerceโ it will 
generally be โstruck down . . . without further inquiry.โ Bainbridge v. Turner, 311 F.3d 
1104, 1109 (11th Cir. 2002).17  
Plaintiffs assert that S.B. 4-C facially discriminates against interstate commerce by 
criminalizing entry across Floridaโs border only by certain noncitizens. (DE 4 at 14โ15.) 
Although the Court has determined that a preliminary injunction is appropriate based on

Plaintiffs have the burden of showing these class definitions meet the numerosity,

Cyberguard Corp., 213 F.R.D. 484, 489โ90 (S.D. Fla. 2003)).

https://perma.cc/ABZ6-Q3R7.21 Around 590,000 of those unauthorized immigrants reside 
in Florida. Id. at 17. Those people have various inter-state travel habits, and many have 
no doubt been removed, deported, or left while such orders were outstanding. Given

2.  Commonality and Typicality 
Commonality is met when there are โquestions of law or fact common to the 
class[es.]โ Fed R. Civ P. (23)(a)(2). โCommonality requires the [P]laintiff[s] to demonstrate 
that the class members have suffered the same injury. This does not mean merely that 
they have all suffered a violation of the same provision of law . . . . Their claims must 
depend on a common contentionโfor example, [in a Title VII context,] the discriminatory 
bias on the part of the same supervisor.โ Duke, 564 U.S. at 350.  
Meanwhile, typicality ensures โthe claims or defenses of the representative parties 
are typical of the claims or defenses of the class[es.]โ Fed. R. Civ P. (23)(a)(3). The inquiry 
โturns on โwhether other members have the same or similar injury, whether the action is 
based on conduct which is not unique to the named class plaintiffs, and whether other 
class members have been injured by the same course of conduct.โโ Gayle v. Meade, 614 
F. Supp. 3d 1175, 1231 (S.D. Fla. 2020) (quoting In re Checking Account Overdraft Litig., 
286 F.R.D. 645, 653 (S.D. Fla. 2012)). This nexus exists when โclaims or defenses of the 
class and the class representative arise from the same event or pattern or practice and 
are based on the same legal theory.โ Id. (quoting In re Terazosin Hydrochloride Antitrust 
Litig., 220 F.R.D. 672, 686 (S.D. Fla. 2004)).  
[T]he commonality and typicality requirements . . . tend to merge. Both 
serve  as  guideposts  for  determining  whether  under  the  particular 
circumstances maintenance of a class action is economical and whether 
the named plaintiffโs claim and the class claims are so interrelated that the 
interests of the class members will be fairly and adequately protected in 
their absence. 
 
Dukes, 564 U.S. at 349 n.5 (internal quotations omitted).

Id. at 350. It follows that typicality is also met, as the class representatives challenge the

Defendants argue commonality is defeated because the Court โwould need to

But this misapprehends the inquiry. โ[F]or purposes of [commonality], even a single 
common question will do[.]โ Dukes, 564 U.S. at 359 (internal quotations omitted and 
alterations accepted). In this case, the common questions are core to resolving Plaintiffsโ 
claims and providing effective relief: whether the entry and reentry provisions violate the

Defendants repackage this same argument to challenge the proposed classesโ

requirement. Typicality ensures that the interests of representatives are โso interrelated 
that the interests of the class members will be fairly and adequately protected in their 
absence.โ Dukes, 564 U.S. at 349 n.5. Despite the potential for some class members to

The class must also be structured such that named Plaintiffs โfairly and adequately 
protect the interests of the classโ. Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a)(4). Adequacy of representation 
depends on โ(1) whether plaintiffsโ counsel are qualified, experienced, and generally able 
to conduct the proposed litigation and . . . (2) whether plaintiffs have interests antagonistic 
to those of the rest of the class.โ Cheney, 213 F.R.D. at 495 (internal quotations omitted). 
Defendants do not contest that these requirements are met.  
Plaintiffsโ  counsel  includes  a  large  team  of  attorneys  who  have  significant

interest exist and that they pledge to devote the resources required to effectively litigate 
this case. (DE 5 at 13.) Therefore, Plaintiffsโ counsel are able to conduct the proposed 
litigation.  
Likewise, the named Plaintiffsโ interests are aligned with the class membersโ for 
the same reasons outlined in the Courtโs typicality discussion. The class members are 
those subject to enforcement of S.B. 4-C by virtue of being noncitizens who entered or 
reentered the United States without inspection with plans to enter or reenter Florida, or

4.  Rule 23(b)(2) 
Defendants also do not contest that this case fits within the Rule 23(b)(2) category. 
Rule 23(b)(2) โhas been liberally applied in the area of civil rights.โ Braggs v. Dunn, 317 
F.R.D. 634, 667 (N.D. Ala. 2016). Indeed, โsome courts have gone so far as to say that 
the ruleโs requirements are โalmost automatically satisfied in actions primarily seeking 
injunctive relief.โโ Id. (quoting Baby Neal v. Casey, 43 F.3d 48, 59 (3d Cir. 1994). โThe 
critical inquiry is whether the class members have suffered a common injury that may 
properly be addressed by class-wide injunctive or equitable relief.โ Ibrahim , 326 F.R.D. 
at 701 (S.D. Fla. 2018) (citing Holmes v. Continental Can Co., 706 F.2d 1144, 1155 (11th 
Cir. 1983)); see also Dukes, 564 U.S. at 360 (โThe key to the (b)(2) class is โthe indivisible 
nature of the injunctive or declaratory remedy warrantedโthe notion that the conduct is 
such that it can be enjoined or declared unlawful only as to all of the class members or 
as to none of them.โโ).  
The  proposed  class  members  all  face  the  common  risk  of  being  subject  to 
enforcement of S.B. 4-C, a law Plaintiffs claim is unconstitutional. See Susan B. Anthony 
List, 573 U.S. at 161 (holding the threat of prosecution pursuant to an unconstitutional 
statute was an injury-in-fact). That injury would be addressed for all members of each 
class through a class-wide injunction preventing enforcement of the lawโs entry and 
reentry provisions. And Plaintiffsโ facial constitutional challenge to both provisions of S.B.

D. Scope of the Injunction 
Having established that a preliminary injunction is warranted, the Court addresses 
the scope of the injunction. Following the Courtโs entry of a TRO, local law enforcement 
agencies continued to make arrests for purported violations of S.B. 4-C. See, e.g., (DE 
57-6). Defendants argue that law enforcement agencies, who are not named defendants 
in this action, are not bound by the Courtโs orders. For the reasons set forth below, the 
Court finds that local law enforcement agencies23 are bound by the Courtโs Order and 
cannot make arrests pursuant to S.B. 4-C unless the Court enters a future order dissolving 
the injunction or a higher reviewing court modifies or overrules this Order. 
Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 65 provides that a Courtโs injunctive power binds 
the parties; the partiesโ officers, agent, servants, employees, and attorneys; and other 
persons who are in active concert or participation with the parties or their officers, agents, 
servants, employees, and/or attorneys. Fed. R. Civ. P. 65(d)(2).   
 
23 To avoid any confusion, the Court clarifies that local law enforcement agencies, as 
used in this section, refers to statewide law enforcement agencies such as Florida 
Highway  Patrol  and  Florida  Department  of  Law  Enforcement,  along  with  any  other 
municipal  or  county  law  enforcement  agencies  throughout  the  state  of Florida  who 
present cases to the named state attorneys and the Attorney General for prosecution.

This [rule] is derived from the common[-]law doctrine that a decree of 
injunction not only binds the parties defendant but also those identified with 
them in interest, in โprivityโ with them, represented by them or subject to their 
control. In essence it is that defendants may not nullify a decree by carrying 
out prohibited acts through aiders and abettors, although they were not 
parties to the original proceeding. 
 
Regal  Knitwear  Co.  v.  N.L.R.B.,  324  U.S.  9,  14  (1945).  It  is  undisputed  that  law 
enforcement  agencies  are  not  named  parties  in  this  action.  Defendants  argue  that 
Floridaโs law enforcement officers are not: (1) Defendantsโ officers, agents, servants, 
employees,  or  attorneys;  or  (2)  invariably  in  active  concert  or  participation  with 
Defendants. The Court addresses each argument in turn.

2023) (quoting U.S. v. Hall, 472 F.2d 261, 267 (5th Cir. 1972)). โAn injunction is not a 
game of whack-a-mole where the Court must repeatedly issue new injunctions to address 
the Defendantsโ post-injunction craftiness.โ Id. at 885. As both Parties agree, the agent 
or servant inquiry turns on whether the bound Party controls the other. See (DE 56 at 6) 
(โTo fall within the common-law definition of all the categories listed in Rule 65(d)(2), law-
enforcement officers must be subject to Defendantsโ control and wield authority to act on

binds โthose . . . subject to [Defendantsโ] controlโ).

2.  Active Concert or Participation 
โ[A] district court may bind nonparties โwho are in active concertโ with a defendant, 
Fed. R. Civ. P. 65(d)(2)(C), . . . when a plaintiff validly invokes federal jurisdiction by 
satisfying  the  traceability  and  redressability  requirements  of  standing  against  a 
defendant.โ Jacobson, 974 F.3d at 1255. As discussed, supra, Plaintiffs have validly 
invoked the Courtโs jurisdiction and established standing. Therefore, the only question 
remaining before the Court is whether local law enforcement departments are in active 
concert or participation with Defendants.   
โSubsection Cโs active concert or participation criterion is directed to the actuality 
of concert or participation, without regard to the motives that prompt the concert or 
participation.โ Al Otro Lado v. Wolf, 497 F. Supp. 3d 914, 929 (S.D. Cal. 2020). Put 
another way, 
[t]he phrase โin active concert or participationโ in no respect implies any 
conspiratorial, devious, or insidious intent or design by [the parties]. The 
phrase โin active concert or participationโ stands in Rule 65 in the ordinary 
and usual sense and means a purposeful acting of two or more persons 
together or toward the same end, a purposeful acting of one in accord with 
the ends of the other, or the purposeful act or omission of one in a manner 
or by a means that furthers or advances the other. 
 
Est. of Kyle Thomas Brennan v. Church of Scientology Flag Serv. Org., Inc., No. 809-CV-
264-T-23EAJ, 2010 WL 4007591, at *2 (M.D. Fla. Oct. 12, 2010). โAn arrest is the initial 
stage of a criminal prosecution.โ Terry v. Ohio, 392 U.S. 1, 26 (1968). Therefore, when 
law enforcement agencies conduct arrests pursuant to S.B. 4-C, they do so in order for 
named Defendants to file and prosecute charges under the Statute. In other words, law 
enforcement agencies conduct arrests to allow the named Defendants to enforce S.B. 4-
C by initiating prosecution. As Defendants acknowledged during oral argument: โThere is

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 67   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/29/2025   Page 49 of 49
2025. The Parties are COMPELLED to attend a Show Cause Hearing on May 
29, 2025 at 2:00 p.m. before the Honorable Kathleen M. Williams in Room 11-3 of 
the Wilkie D. Ferguson, Jr. United States Courthouse, located at 400 North Miami 
Avenue in Miami, Florida. Defendants must be prepared to discuss why sanctions 
should not be imposed for AG Uthmeierโs failure to comply with a Court order. 
DONE AND ORDERED in Chambers in Miami, Florida, on this 29th day of April, 2025.
