documents.title: Order
documents.text:
Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 28   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/04/2025   Page 1 of 14
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA 
CASE NO. 25-21524-CV-WILLIAMS 
 
FLORIDA IMMIGRANT COALITION, et al., 
 
Plaintiffs, 
 
v. 
 
JAMES UTHMEIER, et al., 
 
  Defendants. 
___________________________________/ 
 
ORDER 
THIS  MATTER  is  before  the  Court  on  Plaintiffsโ  Motion  for  a  Temporary 
Restraining Order (โTROโ) and Preliminary Injunction (DE 4) (โMotionโ).1 For the reasons 
set forth below, the Motion (DE 4) is GRANTED. 
I.  BACKGROUND 
On February 13, 2025, Florida Senate Bill 4-C (โS.B. 4-Cโ) went into effect. S.B. 4-
C creates two new state law offenses: โIllegal Entry by Adult Unauthorized Alien into This 
Stateโ and โIllegal Reentry of an Adult Unauthorized Alien.โ Fla. Stat. ยงยง 811.102โ.103. 
Section 811.102(1) prohibits any โunauthorized alien who is 18 years of age or olderโ2 
from โknowingly enter[ing] or attempt[ing] to enterโ Florida โafter entering the United 
 
1 Plaintiffs have personally served Defendants James Uthmeier, Nicholas B. Cox, and 
Jack Campbell. (DE 23 at 1.) Plaintiffs have conferred with Arthur I. Jacobs, who purports 
to represent all state attorney Defendants, and sent him copies of the Complaint, Motion 
for TRO, and all other filings thus far via email. (Id.) This, along with the facts contained 
within the declarations attached to Plaintiffsโ Class Action Complaint (DE 1), fulfills the 
procedural requirements for issuance of a TRO. Fed. R. Civ. P. 65(b)(1).  
2 An โunauthorized alienโ is defined as anyone unlawfully present in the United States 
under the Immigration and Nationality Act and any other applicable federal law. Fla. Stat. 
ยง 811.101(2) (referring to section 908.111). 
Page 1 of 14 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 28   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/04/2025   Page 2 of 14
States by eluding or avoiding examination or inspection by immigration officersโ (โillegal 
entryโ). A first conviction for illegal entry is a first-degree misdemeanor, requiring a 
mandatory  minimum  sentence  of  nine  monthsโ  imprisonment,  while  subsequent 
convictions are felonies with escalating mandatory minimum sentences. Fla. Stat. ยง 
811.102(1)โ(3). Under subsection 811.103(1), an adult โunauthorized alienโ commits a 
third-degree felony, if they โenter[], attempt[] to enter, or [are] at any time found inโ Florida 
after โhaving been denied admission, excluded, deported, or removed or having departed 
the United States during the time an order of exclusion, deportation, or removal is 
outstandingโ (โillegal reentryโ). Importantly, the scheme requires courts to presume that 
โno conditions of release can reasonably assure the presenceโ of any individual arrested 
under either provision and to order their detention without bond pending disposition of the 
case. Fla. Stat. ยงยง 811.102(5), 811.103(4).   
On April 2, 2025, Plaintiffs filed a Class Action Complaint (DE 1) (โComplaintโ), 
seeking injunctive relief barring enforcement of S.B. 4-C by state and local officials and a 
declaration  that  the  law  violates  the  United  States  Constitutionโs  Supremacy  and 
Commerce Clauses. (DE 1 at 17.) Plaintiffs include individuals V.V. and Y.M. (collectively 
(โIndividual Plaintiffsโ), who allege they are at risk of arrest and prosecution under the 
statute,  and  two  grassroots  membership  organizations,  Farmworker  Association  of 
Florida,  Inc.  (โFWAFโ)  and  Florida  Immigrant  Coalition  (โFLICโ)  (collectively 
โOrganizational Plaintiffsโ), which support members who are similarly at risk.3 (Id. ยถยถ 8, 
 
3 Plaintiffs filed a Motion for Class Certification (DE 5), seeking certification of two classes 
with individuals potentially subject to the โillegal entryโ and โillegal reentryโ provisions of 
S.B. 4-C. (DE 5 at 1.) That motion is pending before the Court.   
Page 2 of 14 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 28   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/04/2025   Page 3 of 14
11โ24, 26โ28.)  On the same day, Plaintiffs sought a TRO pausing enforcement of S.B. 
4-C pending the Courtโs consideration of their request for a preliminary injunction. (DE 4.)  
II.  LEGAL STANDARD 
Rule 65 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure authorizes courts to grant a 
preliminary injunction or temporary restraining order before final judgment in limited 
circumstances. The purpose of this injunctive relief is to โpreserve the status quo until the 
[Court] renders a meaningful decision on the merits.โ Schiavo ex rel. Schindler v. Schiavo, 
403 F.3d 1223, 1231 (11th Cir. 2005). The primary difference between a preliminary 
injunction and TRO is that a TRO โmay be entered before the defendant has an adequate 
opportunity to respond.โ Dragados USA, Inc. v. Oldcastle Infrastructure, Inc., No. 20-cv-
20601, 2020 WL 733037, at *2 (S.D. Fla. Feb. 13, 2020). As such, the duration of a TRO 
is limited to fourteen days, absent an extension for good cause. Fed. R. Civ. P. 65(b)(2).  
To merit a TRO, as with a preliminary injunction, Plaintiffs must show:  
(1) a substantial likelihood of success on the merits; (2) that the [TRO] is 
necessary  to  prevent  irreparable  injury;  (3)  that  the  threatened  injury 
outweighs the harm the [TRO] would cause the other litigant; and (4) that 
the [TRO] would not be averse to the public interest. 
 
Gissendaner v. Commโr, Ga. Dept. of Corr., 779 F.3d 1275, 1280 (11th Cir. 2015) 
(quoting Wellons v. Commโr, Ga. Dept. of Corr., 754 F.3d 1260, 1263 (11th Cir. 
2014)); see also Windsor v. United States, 379 F. Appโx 912, 916โ17 (11th Cir. 
2010) (explaining that โthe four criteria for obtaining a preliminary injunction are 
identical to those for issuance of a temporary restraining orderโ). Plaintiffs bear 
โthe burden of persuasion to clearly establish all four of these prerequisites.โ Wreal, 
LLC v. Amazon.com, Inc., 840 F.3d 1244, 1247 (11th Cir. 2016).  
    
Page 3 of 14 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 28   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/04/2025   Page 4 of 14
III.  DISCUSSION 
As a preliminary matter, the Court must address Plaintiffsโ standing to seek their 
requested relief. See Farmworker Assโn of Fla. v. Moody, 734 F. Supp. 3d 1311, 1321 
(S.D. Fla. 2024) (deciding the โthreshold matterโ of the plaintiffsโ standing before reaching 
the merits of their preliminary injunction request). Next, the Court will discuss why the four 
factors relevant to injunctive relief favor granting a TRO in this case.  
A. Plaintiffs have standing to bring this action. 
Plaintiffs who invoke โthe jurisdiction of a federal court bear[] the burden to show 
โ(1) an injury in fact, meaning an injury that is concrete and particularized, and actual or 
imminent, (2) a causal connection between the injury and the causal conduct, and (3) a 
likelihood that the injury will be redressed by a favorable decision.โโ CAMP Legal Def. 
Fund, Inc. v. City of Atlanta, 451 F.3d 1257, 1269 (11th Cir. 2006) (quoting Granite State 
Outdoor Advert., Inc. v. City of Clearwater, 351 F.3d 1112, 1116 (11th Cir. 2003)).  
โInjury in fact reflects the statutory requirement that a person be adversely affected 
or aggrieved, and it serves to distinguish a person with a direct stake in the outcome of a 
litigationโeven though smallโfrom a person with a mere interest in the problem.โ Arcia 
v. Fla. Sec'y of State, 772 F.3d 1335, 1340 (11th Cir. 2014) (quoting United States v. 
Students Challenging Regul. Agency Procs., 412 U.S. 669, 689 n.14 (1973)). An injury-
in-fact  is  โan  invasion  of  a  legally  protected  interest  which  is  (a)  concrete  and 
particularized and (b) actual or imminent, not conjectural or hypothetical.โ Lujan v. Defs. 
of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 560 (1992) (citations omitted). 
 
  
Page 4 of 14 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 28   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/04/2025   Page 5 of 14
1.  Individual Plaintiffs 
V.V. is a FWAF member who was previously deported and last reentered the 
United States without inspection in 2014. (DE 1 ยถ 16.) She now lives in Florida with her 
husband and her four U.S.-citizen children. (Id.) Y.M. is a FLIC member living in Florida, 
who entered the United States without inspection more than twenty years ago. (Id. ยถยถ 26โ
27.) Y.M. leaves Florida twice a year with her minor U.S.-citizen son who has a disability. 
(Id. ยถยถ 26โ27.) Individual Plaintiffs argue that they are at imminent risk of arrest and 
detention as they are subject to prosecution and imprisonment under the language of S.B. 
4-C. (Id. ยถ 59.) โWhen the harm alleged is prospective, as it was here, a plaintiff can satisfy 
the injury-in-fact requirement by showing imminent harm. While the threatened future 
injury cannot be merely hypothetical or conjectural, probabilistic harm is enough.โ Arcia, 
772 F.3d at 1341 (citations omitted). As law enforcement agencies in Florida have already 
made several arrests pursuant to S.B. 4-C, the Court finds that there is a realistic 
probability that Individual Plaintiffs could be subject to arrest and prosecution under S.B. 
4-C. It is irrelevant that they have not yet been arrested or prosecuted: โWhen an 
individual  is  subject  to  [the  threatened  enforcement  of  a  law],  an  actual  arrest, 
prosecution, or other enforcement action is not a prerequisite to challenging the law.โ 
Susan B. Anthony List v. Driehaus, 573 U.S. 149, 158 (2014). Consequently, Individual 
Plaintiffs have sufficiently established an injury-in-fact for standing purposes.  
2.  Organizational Plaintiffs 
For the reasons discussed, infra, the Court finds that Individual Plaintiffs have 
standing. Therefore, it is unnecessary for the Court to engage in a full standing analysis 
of the claims made by Organizational Plaintiffs. See Greater Birmingham Ministries v. 
Page 5 of 14 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 28   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/04/2025   Page 6 of 14
Secโy of State for State of Alabama, 992 F.3d 1299, 1317 (11th Cir. 2021); see also 
Glassroth v. Moore, 335 F.3d 1282, 1293 (11th Cir. 2003) (โHaving concluded that those 
two plaintiffs have standing, we are not required to decide whether the other plaintiff . . . 
has standing.โ). But see Farmworker Assโn of Fla., 734 F. Supp. 3d at 1328 (finding 
farmworker association had organizational standing to challenge alien transportation law 
because the lawโs enforcement would impair the organizationโs ability to engage in its 
projects and divert resources to counteracting the lawโs effects). 
3.  Traceability & Redressability 
Finally, โ[w]hen traceability and redressability are at stake, the key questions are 
who caused the injury and how it can be remedied.โ City of S. Miami v. Governor, 65 F.4th 
631, 640 (11th Cir. 2023). Here, the injury is arrest and prosecution under S.B. 4-C. 
Plaintiffs  contend  that  Defendant  Attorney  General  of  Florida  and  the  remaining 
Defendants are empowered to enforce S.B. 4-C. (DE 1 ยถ 30โ32.) Therefore, at this 
juncture, Plaintiffsโ threatened arrest and prosecution are traceable to Defendants based 
on their general authority to enforce and bring prosecutions under the criminal laws of 
Florida. See Georgia Latino All. for Human Rts. v. Governor of Georgia, 691 F.3d 1250, 
1260 (11th Cir. 2012) (โGLAHRโ) (plaintiffsโ risk of arrest and prosecution under criminal 
law was traceable to passage of the bill and redressable by an injunction).    
To determine redressability, the Court focuses โon whether the injury that a plaintiff 
alleges is likely to be redressed through the litigation.โ Sprint Commcโns Co., L.P. v. APCC 
Servs., Inc., 554 U.S. 269, 287 (2008) (emphasis in original). โ[I]t must be the effect of the 
courtโs  judgment  on  the  defendantโnot  an  absent  third  partyโthat  redresses  the 
plaintiffโs injury, whether directly or indirectly.โ Lewis v. Governor of Alabama, 944 F.3d 
Page 6 of 14 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 28   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/04/2025   Page 7 of 14
1287, 1301 (11th Cir. 2019) (citations omitted). Defendants are state officials tasked with 
the enforcement of S.B. 4-C and empowered to prosecute individuals who do not comply 
with the law. As Defendantsโ authority to enforce S.B. 4-C causes Plaintiffsโ injuries, 
enjoining Defendants from doing so will directly redress those injuries. Put another way, 
Plaintiffsโ requested reliefโan order declaring the entry and reentry provisions of S.B. 4-
C to be unlawful and enjoining Defendantsโ from enforcing those provisionsโwill directly 
redress Plaintiffsโ reasonable fear that the challenged law will be enforced against them 
or their members by Defendants. Given that Plaintiffs have standing, the Court will 
address the remainder of the factors governing their TRO request.  
B. Plaintiffs have fulfilled the criteria for issuance of a TRO 
In order to obtain a TRO, Plaintiffs must establish the four prerequisites noted 
supra p. 3. The Court addresses each.  
1.  Likelihood of success on the merits 
Plaintiffs argue S.B. 4-C violates the Supremacy Clause by creating a statutory 
scheme in an area exclusively reserved for the federal government that conflicts with 
existing federal immigration law and its enforcement. (DE 4 at 5); see U.S. Const. art. VI 
(making federal law the โsupreme Law of the Landโ). Plaintiffs further contend that S.B. 
4-C runs afoul of the Commerce Clauseโs implicit limitation on statesโ power to restrict the 
interstate movement of people. (DE 4 at 14); see U.S. Const. art. I, ยง 8, cl. 3 (giving 
Congress the power to โregulate Commerce with foreign Nations, and among the several 
States, and with the Indian Tribesโ). The Court agrees that, at this early stage, Plaintiffs 
have shown they are likely to succeed on the merits. 
   
Page 7 of 14 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 28   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/04/2025   Page 8 of 14
a.  Supremacy Clause  
States are preempted under the Supremacy Clause โfrom regulating conduct in a 
field that Congress, acting within its proper authority, has determined must be regulated 
by its exclusive governance.โ Arizona v. United States, 567 U.S. 387, 399 (2012) (holding 
the  field  of  alien  registration  is  field  preempted).  In  1952,  Congress  passed  the 
Immigration and Nationality Act (โINAโ), 8 U.S.C. ยง 1101, et seq., a comprehensive 
framework regulating the entry, presence, and removal of noncitizens. See Patel v. 
Garland, 596 U.S. 328, 331 (2022) (โCongress has comprehensively detailed the rules by 
which noncitizens may enter and live in the United States. When noncitizens violate those 
rules, Congress has provided procedures for their removal.โ); GLAHR, 691 F.3d at 1263โ
64 (โT]he federal government has clearly expressed more than a โperipheral concernโ with 
the entry, movement, and residence of aliens within the United States . . . and the breadth 
of [the INA] illustrates an overwhelmingly dominant federal interest in the field.โ) (holding 
Georgiaโs statutes criminalizing transporting, moving, harboring, or inducing an illegal 
alien to enter the state were field preempted); see also 8 U.S.C. ยงยง 1325, 1326 (creating 
a federal statutory scheme criminalizing illegal entry and reentry into the United States). 
Thus, the federal government has exercised its โbroad, undoubted power over the subject 
of immigration and the status of aliens.โ Arizona, 567 U.S. at 394. As in the areas of alien 
registration and transportation, the INAโs comprehensive regulation over noncitizen entry 
and reentry likely preempts any state regulation covering the field.  
Provisions within S.B. 4-C that define illegal entry and reentry through reference 
to federal law,4 or create affirmative defenses where the federal government has given 
 
4 See supra n.2.  
Page 8 of 14 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 28   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/04/2025   Page 9 of 14
an individual reprieve from deportation or removal,5 do not save the statute. โWhere 
Congress  occupies  an  entire  field  .  .  .  even  complementary  state  regulation  is 
impermissible.โ Arizona, 567 U.S. at 401; see also United States v. Texas, 97 F.4th 268, 
286 (5th Cir. 2024) (dismissing Texasโs argument that illegal reentry provisions which 
โmirrorโ the federal equivalent are permissible as โignor[ing] the basic premise of field 
preemptionโthat States may not enter, in any respect, an area the Federal Government 
has reserved for itself.โ) (internal quotations omitted). 
Moreover, โstate laws are preempted when they conflict with federal law.โ Arizona, 
567  U.S.  at  399.  This  includes  when  compliance  with  both  laws  is  a  โphysical 
impossibility[,]โ but also when a challenged law simply impedes โthe accomplishment and 
execution of the full purposes and objectives of Congress.โ Id. (first quoting Fla. Lime & 
Avocado Growers, Inc. v. Paul, 373 U.S. 132, 142โ43 (1963) and then quoting Hines v. 
Davidowitz, 312 U.S. 52, 62 (1941)). For example, even when Arizona imposed a state 
law penalty for conduct already proscribed by the federal government, willful failure to 
complete  or  carry  an  alien  registration  card,  the  Supreme  Court  concluded  that 
โ[permitting] the State to impose its own penalties for the federal offenses here would 
conflict with the careful framework Congress adopted.โ Arizona, 567 U.S. at 402. The 
state  could  prosecute  violations  even  when  federal  officials  determined  they  would 
โfrustrate federal policies.โ Id.; see also GLAHR, 691 F.3d at 1265 (โBy confining the 
prosecution of federal immigration crimes to federal court, Congress limited the power to 
pursue those cases to the appropriate United States Attorney.โ). Further, inconsistencies 
between penalties under the state and federal schemes create a conflict. Arizona, 567 
 
5 See Fla. Stat. ยง 811.102(4). 
Page 9 of 14 
 

Case 1:25-cv-21524-KMW   Document 28   Entered on FLSD Docket 04/04/2025   Page 10 of 14
U.S. at 402โ03 (state laws precluding a sentence of probation conflicted with federal laws 
allowing probation for the same conduct).  
S.B. 4-C appears to suffer from the same infirmities as the alien registration law 
struck down in Arizona. First, it gives state officials authority to prosecute illegal entry or 
reentry in cases where federal actors may choose not to. Even when federal officials 
choose to commence dual prosecutions under both laws, S.B. C-4โs mandatory detention 
provision limits federal law enforcement discretion to recommend pre-trial release and 
obstructs federal courtsโ ability to conduct proceedings requiring defendantsโ presence. 
Additionally, S.B. 4-C requires mandatory prison sentences for state law violations where 
the INA allows for a fine or probation for the equivalent federal crime. Compare Fla. Stat. 
ยง 811.102 (mandating a minimum of a nine-month prison sentence for a first illegal entry 
conviction), with 8 U.S.C. ยง 1325(a) (authorizing a maximum prison sentence of six 
months but not mandating any incarceration upon a first improper entry).   
Finally, across the country, courts have concluded that nearly identical illegal entry 
and  reentry  laws are  likely  preempted  on both  grounds  by federal  immigration  law 
governing noncitizen entry. See e.g., United States v. Iowa, 126 F.4th 1334, 1346 (8th 
Cir. 2025) (affirming preliminary injunction against Iowaโs illegal entry and reentry law, 
after holding the law conflicts โwith federal law because it creates a parallel scheme of 
enforcement for immigration law.โ); Texas, 97 F.4th at 287โ88 (holding Texas had not 
shown its illegal entry scheme was not both field and conflict preempted by federal law); 
United States v. Oklahoma, 739 F. Supp. 3d 985, 999 (W.D. Okla. 2024) (โ[T]here is 
strong support for the conclusion that Congress has legislated so comprehensively in the 
field  of  noncitizen  entry  and  reentry  that  it  left  no  room  for  supplementary  state

In short, โ[f]or nearly 150 years, the Supreme Court has held that the power to 
control immigrationโthe entry, admission, and removal of noncitizensโis exclusively a 
federal power.โ Texas, 97 F.4th at 278โ79. Plaintiffs persuasively posit that S.B. 4-C 
unlawfully encroaches upon that power.  
b.  Commerce Clause  
Plaintiffs  also  argue  S.B.  4-C  violates  the  Commerce  Clause,  which  gives 
Congress power to โregulate Commerce with foreign Nations, and among the several 
States, and with the Indian Tribes.โ U.S. Const. art. I, ยง 8, cl 3; see (DE 4 at 14). That 
power  โencompasses  the  movement  in  interstate  commerce  of  persons  as  well  as 
commodities.โ United States v. Guest, 383 U.S. 745, 758โ59 (1966); see also Edwards 
v.  California,  314  U.S.  160,  172  (1941)  (โ[I]t  is  settled  beyond  question  that  the 
transportation of persons is โcommerceโ, within the meaning of theโ Commerce Clause). 
Implicit in Congressโs power to regulate interstate commerce is an โimplicit or โdormantโ 
limitation on the authority of the States to enact legislation affecting interstate commerce.โ 
Fla. Transp. Servs., Inc. v. Miami-Dade Cnty., 703 F.3d 1230, 1243 (11th Cir. 2012). 
When a scheme โdirectly regulates or discriminates against interstate commerceโ it will

Here,  Plaintiffs  assert  that  S.B.  C-4  facially  discriminates  against  interstate 
commerce by criminalizing entry across Floridaโs border only by certain noncitizens. (DE

determined similar statutes violate the dormant Commerce Clause on this basis. E.g., 
Edwards, 314 U.S. at 174, 177 (striking down Californiaโs ban on transportation of

restricting interstate commerce); United States v. Texas, 719 F. Supp. 3d 640, 679 (W.D. 
Tex. 2024) (holding โ[o]n its face, [Texasโ illegal entry law] discriminates against foreign 
commerce,โ so violates the dormant Commerce Clause). Therefore, at this juncture, 
Plaintiffsโ Commerce Clause analysis also supports their request for a TRO.  
2.  Irreparable injury 
Plaintiffs argue that, absent an immediate pause to enforcement of S.B. 4-C, they will 
suffer irreparable harm by being placed at risk of arrest, prosecution, and detention under 
an unconstitutional state statute. (DE 4 at 16.) In their Supplemental Response, Plaintiffs 
note several reports documenting recent arrests pursuant to S.B. 4-C. (DE 23 at 2.) One 
news source quotes the Brevard County Sheriff Wayne Ivey stating his office was โseeing 
cases like this six to seven times a week.โ Space Coast Daily, First Arrest Made Under

3.  Balance of equities and public interest 
For similar reasons, the balance of equities and the public interest favors granting a 
TRO. โThese two factors merge when, as here, the government is the opposing party.โ 
Farmworker Assโn of Fla., 734 F. Supp. 3d at 1342. The harm to Defendants from briefly 
suspending enforcement of S.B. 4-C is minimal, especially given that similar federal 
provisions already exist and may be enforced against appropriate persons in Florida. 
More importantly, the Court has already determined Plaintiffs are likely to succeed on the 
merits, and Defendants have โno legitimate interest in enforcing an unconstitutional law.โ 
Honefund.com Inc. v. Governor, 94 F.4th 1272, 1283 (11th Cir. 2024) (internal quotations 
omitted).
